HEADLINE: In Island's Wealthiest Area, Backlash Against the Poorest 

BYLINE:  By JULIA C. MEAD

 BODY:
THE SOUTH FORK has reverberated for many years with the buzz of lawn mowers pushed by Latino laborers and vacuum cleaners pushed by Hispanic housekeepers. But there's a new sound filling the air here: increasingly shrill echoes of the nationwide debate over the impact of Spanish-speaking immigrants.
 Natives of Mexico, Central and South America, and the Caribbean have flocked to the region for at least two decades, and many of the earlier arrivals are now established as citizens or legal residents, homeowners, business owners and community leaders. But much of the resentment seems to have been generated by the largest and most recent wave of immigrants who have made the sound of Spanish conversation commonplace in the shops and schools and on the sidewalks of Southampton and East Hampton towns. 
 "It affects us on every level, like an invasion," said Tammy Morgan, who lives in Southampton. She said her son is the only English-speaking student in his 11th-grade math class, her daughter was required to study Spanish from kindergarten through sixth grade, "then you add on top of that that many of them are illegals, they drive without licenses and insurance, they commit crimes, they live in overcrowded group rentals." 
In public meetings and on the letters pages of the local newspapers, Ms. Morgan and other residents are calling for deportations, stepped-up police action, legislative reform, an end to overcrowded housing and the hiring of undocumented workers, sanctions against employers who do hire illegals, and more.
It is a debate that is familiar up-Island, especially in Farmingville, which for several years has been one of the East Coast's hot spots for tensions over illegal immigration. But this year it has sprung forth, full-throated, in the Hamptons, which for better or worse is the genteel, sophisticated face that Long Island presents to the rest of the world. 
Fernando Bustamante was a restaurant dishwasher when he came here 25 years ago from Colombia. He is now a United States citizen and owns Warren's Nursery in Water Mill and Southampton. "People say I brought all these Latinos to the Hamptons, but I tell them businesses here can't make it without them," he said. "American kids don't want to work this hard. It's intensive labor to dig a hole for a 20-foot tree."
Like other established Hispanic-Americans, Mr. Bustamante blames both sides for the growing animosity. Too many recent immigrants are slow to assimilate and too many Anglos lack tolerance, he said. "We have to educate people before we punish them," he said. "I see hostility every day, but that's just ignorance. I tell my workers, 'You have to believe in what you're doing and why you're doing it."'
The 2000 census put Hispanics at 12 percent of the South Fork's population, but there is general agreement on the South Fork that Hispanics comprise closer to quarter of the two towns' residents, a ratio reflected in many of the public schools' student bodies.
Kathleen Bouker of East Hampton said she was prompted to write her own letter to a local paper after noticing more Latinos moving into her neighborhood.
"I'm sorry, but I don't feel they should be able to have 20 people living in one house," she said. "It looks terrible to have six or seven cars in the driveway. They don't have insurance, so they go to the public clinic. They're illegal and they don't pay taxes, but they send their children to our schools. So my school taxes go up and everybody else's do too."
William Kalbacher, an East Hampton builder, blew the whistle earlier this month on a fellow contractor who hired illegal aliens to landscape an East Hampton Village green. Like Ms. Morgan and Ms. Bouker, Mr. Kalbacher was quick to assert he is not anti-Latino but anti-illegal immigration. "I love the Latino people," he said, "but I make sure that whoever works on my job site is legit. So should everyone else."
But that's not how the day laborers who congregate in front of the 7-Eleven in Southampton Village and the East Hampton Village train station see it. On a recent morning, more than 50 were scattered around the 7-Eleven parking lot and a grassy field across the street. Some said they resented the hostility but had no alternative but to stay.
"We only want work," said Juan Hernandez Olvera, a Mexican immigrant who spent the past 11 years traveling through Texas, Georgia, the Carolinas, and New York in search of steady employment. "There are no jobs in Mexico. We have to live."
At 63, he was by far one of the elders on the corner. Mr. Hernandez said he waits there until 11 p.m. or noon for a contractor to hire him, generally at $10 or $12 an hour, before he takes the bus home to a rented room he shares with three other men. "This time of year is very bad," he said.
A man who called himself Juan Condor and said he emigrated from Ecuador three years ago, said through an interpreter that the day laborers see that the anti-immigrant sentiment they faced in other places, such as California and Texas, was now brewing on the South Fork. Mr. Condor, who called it "racism," said he had learned the best defense was to "follow all the rules."
He said he does not own a car and was once stopped by a police officer while walking. "He wanted to know where I was going and where I lived," Mr. Condor said. "I felt like a terrorist or a criminal just for walking down the street." He said he wishes he could go home, but he said he borrowed $13,000 to pay a smuggler to guide him across the border and the man who loaned him the money now has a lien on his house in Ecuador. "I have to stay until it's paid," he said, grimacing.
Several others talked about employers who hired them, then refused to pay. The stories of exploitation and discrimination sparked formation last year of Organizacion Latino Americana, known as OLA. The advocacy group, run by Latin-Americans, has been holding public meetings, documenting complaints of discrimination, lobbying local government for improved services and the state attorney general's office to enforce legal protections, and mediating disputes between Anglos and Latinos.
OLA has also chartered two buses for next month's nationwide "Freedom Ride," when hundreds of thousands are expected to make the cross-country trek to call for immigration reform. Handing out flyers, Isabel Sepulveda de Scanlon, OLA's president, told the day laborers a strong turnout would "show everyone we are here and how badly changes are needed." They read the flyers and nodded.
Latinos are divided by the differences among their own cultures, but she said the growing number of advocacy groups is helping them coalesce into a political force.
"Look around," said Jacqui Candemir, OLA's vice president. "Who's working at CVS, Kmart, the banks, King Kullen, Burger King, inside town hall? Even some of the volunteer fire departments and ambulance squads have given up their good-old-boy ways and are recruiting Latinos. We're more visible now. The time has come."
But over the past several months, as advocacy groups have given voice to a previously silent minority, the demands to rid the region of illegal immigrants have only grown more strident. This may not be a coincidence; government leaders and advocates described a correlation between how vocal the Hispanic community has become and the decibel level of anti-immigrant criticism.
"They are calling attention to themselves and their issues, which is good," said Diana Dominguez Weir, an East Hampton Town councilwoman of Puerto Rican and Colombian descent. "But being out there makes you a target, right?"
Ms. Weir is sponsoring town legislation to curtail the raucous backyard volleyball games popular among East Hampton's Latinos, which for the past few summers have fueled angry complaints from neighbors about overcrowding, drinking and urinating in public, as well as charges of illegal gambling. 
"Latinos are taxing the system out here and yet they're needed by the system," she said, alluding to the fact that they fill many of the low-paid, unskilled jobs as landscapers, motel chambermaids, restaurant dishwashers, and construction laborers that keep a resort economy running.
"There's been a major change here in the past year, and it's frightening," said Katherine Hartnett, who runs SoLA, an educational program that teaches English and computer skills to some 300 Latinos per week. "We don't have to go to Farmingville to feel that kind of hostility. It's right here."
Two white supremacist skinheads were convicted of severely beating two immigrant day laborers from Farmingville two years ago. This summer, four Farmingville teenagers were charged with burning down a Mexican family's home. 
"I'm horrified at the mean-spirited tone I hear now," Ms. Hartnett added. "For some reason, which is incomprehensible to me, people are feeling now that it's O.K. to be right out there with their hostility and racism. And I worry about where that will lead."
The police say there have been no violent hate crimes against Latinos on the South Fork. Still, they too are concerned.
"We know there are hostilities in the community, some valid and some not, and we have to go into these neighborhoods and resolve the disputes before they get out of hand," said Todd Sarris, chief of the East Hampton Town Police Department. 
Two weeks ago, after neighbors complained bitterly at a town board meeting about the volleyball games, he met with OLA and residents of the most affected neighborhood. Up to four officers at a time spent the weekend monitoring the games there, talking with the hosts and helping to organize a neighborhood watch.
"There was not one violation the entire weekend, but we were able to develop a relationship with the neighborhood," he said. "We'll continue to monitor it, but I'd say the situation appears resolved for now." The town also bowed to OLA's demands to build two volleyball courts at a town park to move the games away from residences.
Chief Sarris and officials from other departments disputed claims that Latinos, illegal or otherwise, commit more crimes than other ethnics group. Any increase in crime involving Latinos has been only proportionate to their population growth, agreed Det. Sgt. Howard Lewis, a spokesman for the Southampton Village force, and Gerard Larsen Jr., the East Hampton Village chief.
But at a contentious public meeting hosted in Southampton last month by Representative Timothy Bishop, the East End's congressman, a man who did notidentify himself called all Latinos "garbage." Among the recent letters to The Southampton Press, a local weekly, one signed by a Capt. Bruce Robertson warned that "today's smiling, subservient Latino becomes tomorrow's Shining Path."
"All you need to do is remove 'Latino' and replace it with 'Irish' and you've got a letter from our paper in 1900 probably," said Joseph Shaw, editor of The Southampton Press. "It's the same sentiment, and it's frightening, but we print those letters because we have to shine a light on what's happening."
Mr. Bishop said members of Sachem Quality of Life, the organization leading the fight in Farmingville against illegal immigration, have attended three of his public meetings in eastern Suffolk and each time made comments he described as "abusive" and "incendiary." He said the group is targeting him for supporting the idea of community hiring halls as a way to get the day laborers off the streets.
The Sachem group's president, Edward Person, confirmed that the group opposes hiring halls, an idea approved by the Suffolk County Legislature but vetoed by the county executive, Robert J. Gaffney, but declined to say whether any members were active on the South Fork.
Ms. Morgan said she and other residents are talking about forming their own group to push for illegal immigrants to be picked up off the streets and deported. "There are plenty of people like me who are resentful and angry," she said. "We feel like we're being ignored."
Mayor Joseph Romanosky of Southampton said village trustees are opposed to a hiring hall there and instead asked immigration and Internal Revenue Service officials to step in, the former to round up and deport illegals and the latter to sanction those who hire them.
"We don't want anything that encourages illegal immigration here," he said.
Hamilton Hoge, who owns HHCM Services, a Southampton-based construction management company, sponsored two of his employees for citizenship as they spent years and thousands of dollars navigating the morass of immigration regulations. He said government leaders and Latino advocates should help illegals achieve legal status. 
"I see their faces in the wintertime, the utter despair at 10 or 11 o'clock in the morning," Mr. Hoge said. "But it's baloney to say we can't find other workers. Just look at the state unemployment lines."
"I don't think there's a person out here who is not affected by this crisis," he added. "At some point, we all have our lawns mowed, our car washed by some guy we don't even know. We should be asking the contractors, 'Who are these guys working in my house? What are you paying them? Are they insured?"'

HEADLINE: Hunting for Work, Many Say They Enjoy Some Company 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER S. STEWART

 BODY:
WHEN Dan Flak lost his job 14 months ago as the information technology manager at Gilbarco, a North Carolina gasoline pump manufacturer, a gaping void opened up in his world. "Losing a job is a lot like losing a family member," said Mr. Flak, 54, who has had a full-time job for most of his life. "Daytime TV isn't any good. You sit there without anything to do and start thinking about the situation and it becomes hopeless and lonely."
 Since then, Mr. Flak has become a regular at a few local job groups, where people gather to talk about problems associated with unemployment. Recently, he started one of his own at a local hospital. "There's a comfort in getting out of the house and going to a place where all 40 people are in the same boat as you," Mr. Flak said. "For the moment, these groups are very important to me." 
 With unemployment near a nine-year high and over two million Americans out of work for more than 27 weeks, according to the Labor Department, many people struggling with job searches are finding refuge in job groups. It is hard to say exactly how many job-focused gatherings there are nationwide, because most of the groups are grass-roots efforts operating out of churches and local municipal buildings with no central organizing body. Still, Donald R. Teff, a New York City management consultant specializing in placing people in jobs, speaks at many such gatherings, and he estimates their number to be in the thousands.
"As the economy slides, the calls for help increase and that drives a heavy volunteer response," Mr. Teff said. "The amount of groups nationwide ebbs and flows with the times. When the economy is the way it is now, the need for them is accelerated and you have many, many more." 
Typically, job groups have free admission and they meet early in the morning or after hours at local churches or government offices. Some groups are highly structured with a specific schedule of speakers, job-hunting strategies and financial advice. Others are more open-ended, and the conversation might stray to what some participants call "pity sessions."
After being laid off 18 months ago from SPSS, a software company in Chicago, Susan Greenberg, a 38-year-old M.B.A., made a habit of visiting a couple of groups a week. For her, the groups were less about strategy than about motivation. "At 10, I have to be there," she said. "So it creates a schedule for me. I put on makeup, do my hair. There's this whole process of getting fixed up and going out to meet people. It's incentive to get going. You're going someplace and getting something done."
Though Ms. Greenberg said she had developed only a few leads from the groups, she continues to go for the human contact. "The biggest thing I miss about being employed is the water cooler talk. You talk about job hunting stuff at the groups, but you also talk about things that are going on in your life or the last episode of 'Friends."'
For some unemployed professionals, the groups humanize the job search and ease the pains of displacement and alienation, especially during long stretches of unemployment. "There are so many people that are depressed and lonely," said Marian J. Karpen, founder of WorkTalk, a nonprofit career development organization on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. "People need to feel like they belong to something. They've been out of work for so long and feel ashamed."
WorkTalk has no set formula for its gatherings, but they usually involve round-table discussions about job hunting and a speaker on subjects like leadership, interview etiquette and financial strategies. "There is no magic solution," said Ms. Karpen, who has been running the group for nearly 12 years and has recently seen an increase in the number of new faces. "But these groups give you exposure to more angles than the self-help books or the Internet." 
Some also find that the groups offer useful networking opportunities. John Schegg, vice president and managing director of Goodrich & Sherwood Associates, a human resources firm based in New York, is the host of nine networking-oriented job groups in Connecticut organized by professional specialties like human resources, financial or sales and marketing.
The groups are kept to 30 people and meet for two hours every other week, allowing members to exchange leads and talk about different job-seeking approaches. Some 75 percent of those attending have landed jobs in the last year, Mr. Schegg said, and that has definitely been noticed. "I get phone calls continuously now, and have to turn a lot of people down," he said. "I'd say we get an average of six phone calls a day for these groups."
Duane Elms was able to land a spot at Mr. Schegg's meetings. Just over two years ago, he was laid off from TranSwitch, a telecommunications and semiconductor company in Shelton, Conn., where he was a product marketing manager. He began attending five groups with Mr. Schegg, and four other groups also in Connecticut. "It made me feel like I had an actual job," Mr. Elms said. "I dressed up for them just like I was going into the office."
Mr. Elms, 58, estimates that in 25 months he has attended over 350 job groups, looked at hundreds of thousands of job openings and sent out over 1,500 resumes. The groups helped him persevere when he was discouraged, he said. "If I felt down or hit a wall, there were people there to pick me up," he said.
When he finally got an interview with Western New Mexico University last month for a position as director of information technology, the meetings helped him prepare. "I didn't have any experience with an academic setting and people in the groups had," he said. "They taught me what I needed to know so I could interview effectively."
Mr. Elms was hired by the university and he credits the groups for his success. For the five groups with Mr. Schegg, he brought in doughnuts, a common gesture of thanks from graduates of these meetings, and he told everyone how he landed the job. In late August, he and his wife moved to New Mexico but he continues to stay in touch with some 30 group members. "I'm actually using a guy from the group as a real estate agent to sell our house in Connecticut," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Duane Elms attended a number of job groups before finding work, at Western New Mexico University. (Photo by April Hanson)

HEADLINE: Robert Moses' Village Gets Him Back, in Bronze 

BYLINE:  By CAROLINE B. SMITH

DATELINE: Babylon 

 BODY:
ROBERT MOSES, the master planner of New York State's parks and parkways, was a controversial figure during his long and much-accomplished life, and disagreement over his legacy has not faded in the 22 years since his death. But there was little but praise here last Saturday when a bronze statue of Moses was unveiled in a ceremony attended by more than 100 local residents in the village he called home. 
 "It takes a true visionary to transcend not just politics but to be able to deal with all the bureaucracy involved in carrying something to fruition," said Mark Romaine, 39, a three-year Babylon resident who came out for the unveiling. He said he knew about the public outcry over the neighborhoods ruined by Moses' development of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and Cross-Bronx Expressway, but said, "when you take the measure of a man, you have to say that Robert Moses would definitely be on the positive side." 
 Maura Miles-Mason, a consultant to the Babylon Village Public Arts Commission, which oversaw the project with a $190,000 appropriation from Suffolk County, said it was good that the statue found a place on the lawn of Babylon's Village Hall. "Those types of bronzes usually go at a crossroads," she said. "The piece is so worthy of close inspection and contemplation. I'm happy that people can get close to that." 
And they did. The 1,500-pound, seven-foot bronze, by Jose I. Fernandez of Sylmar, Calif., showing Moses with brow furrowed and dressed in suit and tie, was pronounced "a very good likeness" by Carney Maguire, 73, who was a dressmaker to Moses' first wife, Mary Louise. She described him as "gruff, pleasant, firm," a man who "got the job done" and was always on the go.
"That's what we were driving at," said Joy Torrey, 82, a village resident since 1934 and a member of the village arts commission. "Can't you just see the power behind it?" 
Longtime village residents recalled an eccentric man who preferred bare lightbulbs over lampshades to maximize the electricity he paid for, and an unparalleled road-builder who never drove a car but was instead chauffeured around in the back of a limousine. He also never owned but rented his home on Thompson Avenue. 
"He never had money in his pocket," said Judy Skillen, a Babylon resident whose father, Ellison Driscoll, was the photographer for the state Parks Commission for 44 years and often accompanied Moses on business. "My father would pay the tolls," Mrs. Skillen said.
In a career that began in 1924, when he was appointed to head the Long Island region of the state Parks Commission, and ended in 1968, when he gave up control of the last of a dozen state and New York City agencies through which he spent nearly $150 billion (inflation-adjusted) in taxpayer money, Robert Moses adapted New York State's road system to the automobile age, creating every mile of road now designated as parkway and directing construction of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, the Long Island Expressway, 13 major bridges and 2 major tunnels. He also built all the major state parks, the United Nations, Lincoln Center, Shea Stadium and both World's Fairs in Queens, 658 playgrounds in New York City and hydropower plants at Niagara Falls and on the St. Lawrence River. 
Long Island, Moses' home, was his first and favorite canvas. Jones Beach State Park is widely regarded as his masterpiece. But his passion for pavement finally met its limit on the Island, when public opposition forced him to abandon plans to build a cross-Sound bridge from Bayville to Rye and a parkway running the length of Fire Island. The defeats signaled the end of his career.
"Of course he stepped on people's toes. He had to. He was a great man," said Larry Merryman, 68, a Babylon resident since 1967. "All you have to do is drive that grand span along Jones Beach. It could have been a city just like Long Beach if the developers were allowed to get to it." 
"He gave us power, parks and transportation," said former Gov. Hugh Carey, who attended the unveiling. "He could spend money and he got value in return. No economist has ever figured out the return to New York State. You don't need to defend his record. His record is clear. He incorporated safety into everything he built. He overcame opposition so we could all live better today." 
Moses paved the way for three careers in the family of Bob Chapin, whose father, William, was an engineer for Moses in the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and ultimately general manager and chief engineer of the state Power Authority. "He demanded a high degree of capability and he got it," said Bob Chapin, 63, who brought to the unveiling a picture of his father with Moses at Niagara Falls. "He surrounded himself with the best people," said Mr. Chapin, a retired highway engineer for the state Department of Transportation, where his son Steven, 36, now works. 
Babylon's county legislator, David Bishop, said he was aware of Moses' reputation as a petty tyrant. "But you come back to Babylon and people have the opposite perception," Mr. Bishop said. "Yes, he had flaws. But he was what New York needed."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 12, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 28 about the installation of a statue of Robert Moses in Babylon credited him incorrectly with one part of the state's highway construction record. Part of the Bronx River Parkway was built before he became chairman of the New York State Parks Council, in 1924; he was responsible for building the rest of the state's parkways. A picture caption referred incorrectly to Moses' birthplace. It was New Haven; he was not a native son of Babylon.
An article on Sept. 28 about the unveiling of a statue of Robert Moses in Babylon included an erroneous reference from the Village of Babylon Historical & Preservation Society about the ownership of Moses' home. He owned it; he did not rent it. The president of the society corrected the error in a letter dated Oct. 23.

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL; 
Neighbors Collide With Proposed Revival of Freight Line

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: KENILWORTH 

 BODY:
THE rusting railroad tracks pass within 20 feet of the south side of Carol Westervelt's house, a gray Cape Cod on Faitoute Avenue, but no freight train has used them for more than a decade. Having been told by the railroad that the tracks were abandoned, she and her husband extended a hedge from their front yard across them and erected a fence over them in back. 
 The idea was to keep people from dumping garbage along the right of way and cars from taking short cuts to Michigan Avenue, which borders their back yard to the east . Gesturing toward the rail bed one recent morning, she said, "One year we had a drunk who thought this was a street and actually drove down." 
 In many places in Union County, scrub brush has taken over this railroad line. Some people have planted flowers to make the rail bed look a little more pleasing. Few thought the line would be used again. 
But much to the chagrin of many residents, Union County, with the state's blessing, has initiated a plan to rehabilitate some 12 miles of track, through eight towns from Linden to Summit, and to reactivate limited freight service.
The plan, which the Board of Freeholders gave final approval in June, has run into heavy opposition from residents along the route. Their concerns about safety and quality of life have prompted a lawsuit by officials in five towns to derail the plan.
It has also raised questions, including one on the plan's cost. Neither Union County, Morristown & Erie Railway Inc., which the county chose to reactivate the line, nor the State Department of Transportation seems to have a figure because no current cost analysis has been done. 
"We don't have an estimation of the total cost," County Manager George W. Devanney said in a telephone interview.
That alone, says Mayor Michael A. Tripodi of Kenilworth, a leading opponent, makes the viability of the plan questionable, 
"The railroad is supposed to have an operating plan, and they're still developing it," Mayor Tripodi said. "It's a very simple issue. When you're starting up a business you have to have a business plan to know the impact, feasibility, and cost benefit analysis. None of this has been done."
Union County says it can count on $7.5 million from a state transportation bond fund. State transportation officials, however, say state aid amounts to $5.5 million.
Critics contend that clearing debris and vegetation, replacing rotted ties, laying new track, installing warning devices and repairing old bridges, as well as replacing at least three that have been torn down, could cost tens of millions more. 
Mr. Devanney says no county money will be spent and defends the plan as fostering economic development.
"The purpose is to provide service and enhance local business and take trucks off the road by servicing local business," Mr. Devanney said. 
But many argue that freight service ended a decade ago for a lack of business.
"In actual fact, the railroad will bring noise, diesel exhaust pollution and traffic congestion," Herbert Slote, a Springfield resident, wrote in a position paper for a group of residents along the route called Stop the Train. "It will create physical hazards along the at-grade right of way, imperil emergency services, depreciate real estate values and erode the tax base without contributing any economic benefit to the community." 
Mr. Devanney , who indicated the county could not legally stop the train service, said the county made the best deal it could by choosing to contract with a short-line railroad service serving local customers rather than heavy long-distance carriers like CSX and Norfolk Southern, both of which had expressed interest in the lines. 
"We would have all the headaches of a heavy freight service and no benefits to business in Union County," he said.
Under the 10-year contract, three trains with a maximum of 15 cars will be permitted to use the tracks each week in the first year of operation and no more than three to five trains will be permitted per week beginning in the third year. Maximum speed will be 25 miles an hour.
The county will receive a fee of $2 from the M.&E. for use of the track and share in a percentage of the revenue: 8 percent in excess of $65,000 per month up to $155,000 and 10 percent of revenue over $155,000 a month plus 10 percent of rail-related property rights revenue. 
Although critics say the revenue will go toward maintenance, Mr. Devanney said the money would be made available to towns for economic development along the line. 
The current situation evolved when two railroad companies abandoned the lines: the Staten Island Railway Corporation in 1991 and the Rahway Valley Railroad Company in 1992. 
In 1994, the State Department of Transportation bought the lines and in June 2000, Union County signed an agreement with the department to rehabilitate and reactivate them. On May 9, 2002, after seeking requests for proposals from three railroad companies, Mr. Devanney said the county chose M.&E. based on its safety and service record. The Federal Surface Transportation Board approved the agreement that June.
Opponents contend that county officials never gave the municipalities sufficient notice of its plan and then reneged on a promise to abandon it if the municipal governments opposed it. 
"They kept telling us it wasn't going to happen and in the meantime, they had already signed an agreement," said JoAnn Dillon, who with her neighbor, Ms. Westervelt, organized the Stop the Train in the summer of 2002.Mr. Devanney countered by saying that the county transportation advisory board, which includes members appointed by the mayors, had been exploring the resumption of freight service for a decade. In all, there have been more than 100 public meetings, he added. "This is something people have been aware of over the last decade," he said.
Ms. Dillon, a secretary to the Springfield schools superintendent, and Ms. Westervelt, an accountant, went to a council meeting to asked Mayor Tripodi and council members about the plan. "They didn't know what we were talking about," she said. 
In late June 2002, a month and a half after the operating agreement had been reached, the mayors received a letter from Gordon R. Fuller, M.&E. chief operating officer. His company, he said, had been chosen to rehabilitate the line and reactivate service.
In early August, however, the mayors received a letter from Mr. Devanney, who wrote that the track work was meant "to address safety and public health concerns" and that it "should not be viewed as a precursor to the start up of rail service."
As sentiment against the project grew, the Board of Freeholders passed a resolution in late August saying the reactivation would not be approved without consent of the municipalities. Many towns quickly adopted resolutions opposing the project.
In the next year, opponents received assurances from county officials that no train would run without the consent of the towns. But the railroad then threatened to sue the county for breach of contract. 
"After nine months of a legal review, one by a Washington attorney who specialized in transportation and one by a local New Jersey counsel, it was determined that the resolution was unenforceable," Mr. Devanney said. 
As a result, the council made the rail line's reactivation official on June 5, authorizing Mr. Devanney to implement the plan's remaining phases. 
Critics say the procedure the county followed was further flawed because no environmental impact, economic feasibility or traffic and safety studies were conducted.
Mr. Fuller said in a telephone interview, "Environmental impact studies were done when the state took over the property. There's no need to do a new one. What we're doing is replicating what was there before."
Mr. Devanney said the State Department of Transportation was responsible for analyzing traffic and safety issues, but Kris Kolluri, the department's chief of staff, said such a study probably would be necessary only if the track is built into areas currently not on the existing right of way. 
Five of the eight affected towns -- Kenilworth, Roselle, Roselle Park, Springfield and Summit -- filed suit in state Superior Court opposing the plan, pinpointing these and other issues. 
In addition, the five towns have hired a Washington law firm, Patton Boggs with expertise in railroad law to ask the Federal Surface Transportation Board to review its decision allowing resumption of service. 
Stop the Train officials say trains will travel over 28 unprotected crossings at grade. Those crossings include Faitoute Avenue and busy roads like Michigan Avenue here, Westfield Avenue in Roselle Park, Mountain Avenue in Springfield and Route 22 in Union.
"You're talking about reactivating railroad lines that were originally constructed a hundred years ago when this was rural New Jersey," said Bruce H. Bergen, the Springfield Township Attorney.
Opponents question whether the rail service will have enough customers.
"Here they're doing something and they hope people will come," said Robert J. Sheehan, a Summit representative of Stop the Train. "Remember the movie, 'Field of Dreams?' Well it's a field of dreams with our tax money. "
Mr. Fuller, who acknowledged that his company had done no survey of businesses, used the same analogy but in a positive way.
"What we found when we took over the Morristown & Erie, many of the customers we serve now weren't there when we started service," he said. "When you provide service, people will come to you. It's not quite like 'Field of Dreams' but when you have the opportunity to provide rail service to the local customer, yes, we have the customers come to us." 
As for the cost of rehabilitating the tracks and implementing service, he said: "Can't tell yet. We're waiting for information from the state diagnostic team on the type of crossing warning devices that are necessary and we've got several bridges to rebuild and we haven't gotten any information on this yet either." 
He noted that while his company had not done an economic analysis of costs and revenue, "The county and state have."
Mr. Devanney said the county made a preliminary analysis that estimated costs would reach $7.5 million. That figure was included in a county engineering study about five years ago.
And Mr. Kolluri said the state's agreement did not require a cost analysis. Noting that he had not been told the total cost either, he said, "The money we've given is what was asked of us because that was the cost of the project and I've not heard it's going to be more than that."
Mr. Devanney said work on the Staten Island rail line section would be completed in 2004 and the Rahway Valley portion in 2005. He acknowledged that there was not enough money to complete the project and said he did not know where additional money would come from. 
"The current estimate is that $7.5 million will take us to the Township of Union," Mr. Devanney said. "Obviously it will be more expensive than our initial projection. Clearly it's not enough to do the whole job."
Asked what the options were, he said, "If there's no additional funding, that's where it will stop. It will run from Linden to Union."

GRAPHIC: Photos: JoAnn Dillon, left, Bill Dillon and Carol Westervelt, who are neighbors in Kenilworth, are fighting a county proposal to refurbish tracks that run alongside their homes. (Photographs by Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bone Diagnosis Gives New Data But No Answers 

BYLINE:  By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
The disease, if it is a disease, afflicts most middle-aged and elderly women, and a large segment of men. But it has no symptoms, it is not clear what patients should do about it and it is being diagnosed more and more often.
 The condition is osteopenia, or low bone density. It is considered by many doctors to be a first step along the path to osteoporosis, a serious condition in which bone density is extremely low and bones are porous and prone to shatter. But researchers say that while bone density predicts fracture risk, more is involved, including age, family history and a poorly understood factor known as bone quality. 
 Those nuances may be lost, researchers say, as patients fixate on a number -- bone density -- and a diagnosis -- osteopenia -- and fear that unless they take action their fates are sealed. 
Doctors are telling women to find out their bone density as soon as they go through menopause. Younger women as well as middle-aged men are also getting tested.
The tests are easy to come by, with special X-ray machines springing up at hospitals and free-standing screening centers, offering scans for about $125. Small, portable bone density testing machines are turning up in doctors' offices and in shopping centers and drugstores, with scans that cost about $40.
But the painless screening test and quick diagnosis by no means offer patients and doctors a simple answer. Osteopenia, it turns out, is yet another diagnosis that strikes at the core of debates emblematic of modern medicine, when screening can get ahead of treatment, or even the understanding of a condition, medical experts say.
The stakes are particularly high with osteopenia because the number of patients is enormous. One federal study in which more than 14,000 men and women were screened estimated, conservatively, that osteopenia afflicts 13 million to 17 million women and 1 million to 2 million men in this country. 
"Most people would agree that if someone has osteoporosis, you should treat them," said Dr. Ethel Siris, who is a professor of clinical medicine at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons and directs the Toni Stabile Osteoporosis Center at New York Presbyterian Hospital. But, she added, "no one knows what to do about the woman who has quote unquote osteopenia."
Dr. Joan McGowan, chief of the musculoskeletal diseases branch at the National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases, said that, of course, drug companies see a huge market in people with low bone density, and who could blame them?
Also at stake is the calcium supplement market. Many people take calcium supplements in the hope of staving off bone loss. While a large federal study is investigating their effectiveness, researchers say that calcium may have a small effect but is not going to obliterate the effects of menopause or aging.
"It is very difficult for people to accept menopausal bone loss and bone loss from aging without trying to stop it," Dr. McGowan said. "Since every woman in America is going to go through menopause and have accelerated bone loss, every woman in America is a candidate for some type of treatment. The problem we have in the bone field is identifying people who have a high risk of fracture and not those who may be perfectly normal." 
Opinions range from dismissing the condition as largely an invented problem to urging that nearly everyone who has it starts treatment. 
"We have medicalized a nonproblem," said Dr. Michael McClung, director of the Oregon Osteoporosis Center. Most people with the condition, he said, have bone densities that are below average but not below normal. "Only in Lake Wobegon is everyone above average," he said. While some women may need treatment, many more do not, he added.
Dr. James Simon, president of the North American Menopause Society, begs to differ. Once bone starts being lost, it is time to think about taking action, he said, with the only question being how low should bone density go before consideration of treatment begins. He added that, in his opinion, if the drugs were free, "the argument would largely go away."
"Fractures don't wait until you are osteoporotic or barely osteoporotic or osteopenic or barely osteopenic," Dr. Simon said. "Fractures increase with decreases in bone density and once you fracture, you put yourself at a dramatically increased risk of a future fracture."
Complicating the situation is the fall from grace of hormone therapy for menopause. Last year, when a large federal study indicated that the drugs were riskier than many had realized, many women stopped taking them. Doctors are now advising these women to have a bone density test.
"Women going off their hormones has re-upped the ante about whether some alternative treatment should be started," Dr. Simon said. "It really is an issue now."
Drugs to prevent or treat osteoporosis include bisphosphonates like Merck's Fosamax, which permanently bind to bone; parathyroid hormone, which is generally reserved for severe osteoporosis; Eli Lilly's Evista, which acts like estrogen on bone but also can cause hot flashes and blood clots; and calcitonin, a less effective treatment that is administered as a nasal spray. Worldwide sales of osteoporosis drugs reached $3.98 billion last year.
There are no national data on the number of people with osteopenia who are treated. But Merck estimates, from its own market research, that about 8 million women have been found to have osteopenia and about a third of them are taking an osteoporosis drug.
Osteopenia was defined in June 1992 at a World Health Organization meeting in order to prompt governments to pay attention to the problem of bone loss. 
Dr. L. Joseph Melton, an osteoporosis epidemiologist at the Mayo Clinic who attended the meeting, said the group decided to identify a new condition, osteopenia, for people 50 and older with lower than average bone density who did not have osteoporosis. It would encompass a bone density that was one standard deviation below that of a normal young adult. (The group also defined osteoporosis as 2.5 standard deviations or more below that reference point.)
"It was just meant to indicate the emergence of a problem," Dr. Melton said of the definition. "It didn't have any particular diagnostic or therapeutic significance. It was just meant to show a huge group who looked like they might be at risk."
But that is not how it has been interpreted, said Dr. Steven R. Cummings, of the University of California in San Francisco.
"There is no basis, no biological, social, economic or treatment basis, no basis whatsoever, for using minus one." Dr. Cummings said. "As a consequence, though, more than half of the population is told arbitrarily that they have a condition they need to worry about."
One problem is that bone density fails to capture a poorlyunderstood factor known as bone quality, which declines with age, researchers say. 
"A 50-year-old woman with a bone density that is clearly in the osteoporotic range has a much lower risk of having a fracture in the next year or the next five years than an 80-year-old woman with the same bone density," Dr. McGowan said. "It's definitely something about the quality of the bone changing." 
As bone scanning took off, new problems emerged, including what constitutes low bone density in men. 
With women, the standard comparison is to the bone density of a 30-year-old white woman. Comparing men's bones to those of a 30-year-old white man means that nearly half of all middle-aged men have osteopenia, said Dr. Anne Looker of the National Center for Health Statistics. But men have just 35 percent the risk of hip fractures as women.
There also are questions of what different machines are measuring. The first scans were with X-rays, known as Dexa, for dual-energy X-ray abosorptiometry. Newer cheap and portable scanners use ultrasound, and portable X-ray machines measure density in the heel. But a Merck study directed by Dr. Siris found that the prevalence of osteopenia varied from 28 to 45 percent depending on the type of machine.
Then comes the question of whom to treat. While osteoporosis drugs do slow bone loss, it has been difficult to show that they prevent fractures in people with osteopenia, maybe because their fracture rate is already so low. "If people aren't having fractures," Dr. McClung said, "you can't prevent them."
For example, Dr. McClung asked if Fosamax helped in women with osteopenia. After six years, he found, the women taking Fosamax had a higher bone density than women taking a placebo but no fewer fractures. 
It usually takes 10 to 15 years after menopause before women get osteoporosis.
"If you are going to seriously try to prevent hip or spine fractures later in life, you want to be confident that these drugs will work in 5 or 10 years," Dr. Cummings said. "A number of us are concerned that long-term treatments with drugs of this sort that stop the turnover of bone may lead to a lesser effect or no effect or even increase the risk of fracture."
Bones, he explained, are constantly being remodeled, breaking down and growing in a process that, until middle age or so, is in balance. With bisphosphonates, remodeling is slowed. "That turnover in bone, that cellular activity, seems to be a very strong indicator in risk of fractures," Dr. Cummings said. "You want turnover, because if bone is not replaced over 30 years, it can weaken because of microscopic damage. Some of us believe that old, highly mineralized bone is more brittle, more prone to break."
Some osteoporosis experts, like Dr. Siris, follow guidelines issued by the National Osteoporosis Foundation (www.nof.org). She focuses on women and looks at other factors besides bone density. Did the woman have any fractures after menopause? That greatly increases her risk. Does she smoke? Is she small and thin? Does she have a family history of osteoporosis? Is she taking drugs like corticosteroids that suppress the immune system and can increase her risk? Dr. Siris suggests bone density screening for 50-year-old women with additional risk factors for osteoporosis and tells others they can wait until they are 60 or 65.
"You've got to have a strategy for dealing with this huge mass of women," Dr. Siris said. "What do you do?"

GRAPHIC: Photos: Esther Davitt had her bone density checked by Olivia Benoit at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan, above, and spoke to Dr. Ethel Siris, left. More and more middle-aged patients are being checked for low bone density, or osteopenia, but doctors do not agree on how, or even whether, to treat the condition. (Photographs by Jennifer S. Altman for The New York Times)(pg. 28)

HEADLINE: Page Two: Sept. 21-27; 
Expect to Pay More At the Gas Pump

BYLINE:  By Eric Pfanner

 BODY:
YOUR taxes, in a manner of speaking, were raised last week. If you didn't notice, perhaps that is because it happened in Vienna.
 "Old Europe" strikes again? Not quite. While the decision was made in the capital of decadent kaffeehaus culture, the Viennese were simply the hosts for a meeting of OPEC oil ministers, who made life a bit rougher for Americans. 
 The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries has had a quiet couple of decades, losing market share and watching its influence over energy prices wane. In Iraq War II, it took it easy on its customers, pumping more oil to keep prices in check. Perhaps as a result, there has been no real American move to force Iraq, which sits on the world's second-largest oil reserves, out of OPEC.
The oilmen are taking back some of their largesse. Last week, they moved to cut output by 900,000 barrels per day as of Nov. 1, catching the experts by surprise. Prices in the energy markets soared. Soon they should rise at the pump, unless demand slows, Iraq quickly ramps up exports or non-OPEC producers like Russia pick up the slack.
And that means Americans are getting a tax increase. Analysts estimate that a one-cent rise in the price of a gallon of gasoline at the filling station cuts overall consumer spending in the United States by $1 billion.
In some parts of the country, gasoline prices have already been hovering around $2 per gallon. A 5 percent rise -- roughly the amount by which crude-oil prices rose in the two days after the OPEC move -- amounts to about 10 cents, or $10 billion in lost spending. Oil-market math is never that simple, but by any calculation the United States economy suffers when energy prices rise.
Some OPEC officials made noises about possible further cuts, though. They cited the so-called jobless recovery as one factor that will curb demand. Fewer trips to the office mean fewer rides to the mall and fewer stops at the gas station.
Oil ministers also said they were optimistic about Iraq's ability to protect its oil facilities from sabotage, allowing it to raise output to prewar levels by March.
If not, further tax increases may be on the way.
 Eric Pfanner

HEADLINE: WORTH NOTING; 
Another Good News, Bad News Kind of Day

BYLINE:  By Robert Strauss

 BODY:
For Governor McGreevey, the news these days offers a mixed bag. For instance, while voters do not seem to be overly fond of the Governor, they don't think he's the state's biggest problem either. 
 A new Quinnipiac University poll released last week said Mr. McGreevey has broken the 50 percent mark. An all-time high of 52 percent don't think he is doing a good job, as against 35 percent who do. 
 On the other hand, the poll noted that 29 percent of those surveyed think taxes, both income and property, are the state's biggest problem, followed by the 13 percent who blame the economy and 11 percent who cite education. Only 4 percent blame politicians the most for the state's woes, and only half of them single out Governor McGreevey. Robert Strauss

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
Miscasting W.U.S.A.'s Target Audience

BYLINE:  By JERE LONGMAN

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
They came out in force Thursday night for the United States versus Nigeria in the Women's World Cup, the pigtailed hooligans in their Mia Hamm jerseys and painted faces, their voices collected into a familiar shriek of adulation.
 My 13-year-old daughter, Julie-Ann, was not among them. 
 Not that she dislikes soccer. Far from it. She plays on a travel team, once wore her uniform to school on career day and has incorporated her jersey number into her e-mail address. 
She has met many of the American stars, and they have been kind. Hamm signed autographs for her entire team. She has high-fived Julie Foudy on the sideline after W.U.S.A. games and chatted with Brandi Chastain. She keeps their autographs on the wall, beside her pictures of the rapper Eminem and the actor Ashton Kutcher. But she went to soccer practice Thursday, rather than attend the World Cup match.
"It's interesting to play, but boring to watch," Julie-Ann said. "Like baseball."
In a broader sense, I wonder if this adolescent disconnect figured prominently in the recent collapse of the Women's United Soccer Association. Apart from corporate indifference and a weak economy, did the league disengage the very fans who should have been its most ardent supporters?
James Chung thinks so. He is the president of Reach Advisors, a Boston-based marketing research firm serving companies that focus on families and youth. His firm conducted independent consumer research on the W.U.S.A. and found several miscalculations by the league, Chung said in an interview and e-mail correspondence.
First, he said, the W.U.S.A. tried to sell itself to sponsors as a vehicle to reach soccer moms. "Unfortunately," Chung said, "the soccer mom phenomenon is dead. Not that fewer kids are playing soccer, but Generation X moms do not identify themselves as soccer moms as much as their baby boom predecessors. The W.U.S.A. was trying to push a societal trend that prospective sponsors had already discarded."
He refers to advertising for the Nissan Quest that declares, "Moms have changed," a signal that minivan ads are turning 180 degrees from the soccer mom concept.
Secondly, Chung said, the league should have targeted soccer dads, a strategy used by organizers of the hugely successful 1999 Women's World Cup. It is fathers who generally push their daughters into the sport, and who were more likely to buy W.U.S.A. tickets and merchandise, Chung said.
"The W.U.S.A. still subscribed to the theory that family decisions were driven by moms, when a good portion of their ticket sales were actually driven by an audience that they did not address," he said.
Perhaps the most troubling discovery in his research was that girls -- the W.U.S.A.'s core audience -- found the league to be "uncool" once they reached middle school. They became "somewhat embarrassed" to consider themselves fans or to wear league merchandise, he said. When they watched games on television, they tended to watch them alone instead of with friends.
Kate Sobrero, a defender on the national team, said that societal pressures on adolescent girls "made it tough to have your own identity at that age."
Julie-Ann, my daughter, said that a lack of advertising and news media coverage about women's soccer, and women's sports in general, made them less desirable.
"You always know when the Eagles are going to play football, but you never know when there is going to be a soccer game," Julie-Ann said. "If you don't hear about it, you are not going to be interested."
We bought season tickets to Philadelphia Charge matches for the inaugural season in 2001. In 2002, Julie-Ann attended only a couple of matches. This past season, she had zero interest. She keeps a Charge rally towel on the wall in the basement, but as of now, has no Charge to rally. 
An inexperienced W.U.S.A. staff, Chung said, violated a cardinal rule of youth marketing: you do not advertise yourself to the age of your core audience, but to the age your core audience aspires to be.
In other words, if the league had played down "sugar and spice" wholesomeness campaigns meant to attract 8- to 12-year-olds, and sold the concept of the players as strong women, the W.U.S.A. could have kept the youth audience and also made itself relevant to a much wider group of adolescent girls and young women.
"If you speak solely to that 'tween' audience of 8- to 12-year-olds," Chung said, "you almost guarantee the teenage audience will run away from you."
Meanwhile, W.U.S.A. average attendance dipped in each of the league's three seasons, from 8,116 in 2001 to 6,957 in 2003. And the league struggled to attract more than 100,000 television households before suspending operations.
This was disappointing, Chung said, because the W.U.S.A. "had incredibly strong assets to turn itself into one of the coolest brands out there for older girls -- and guys." He added, "But the league would have had to break out of the mind-set that they were selling women's soccer, and start behaving like an entertainment marketer."
Perhaps the mistakes can be corrected. The W.U.S.A. is considering returning in some altered form, with a condensed schedule or with its eight teams concentrated in four cities. He hopes the league survives, Chung said. He is the father of a young daughter and wants the sport to be a part of her life. He would love to become a soccer dad himself. 
"I hope it's not wishful thinking," he said.

HEADLINE: Rock of Ages 

BYLINE:  By Adam Cohen; Adam Cohen, who writes editorials for The Times, is co-author, with Elizabeth Taylor, of "American Pharaoh: Mayor Richard J. Daley: His Battle for Chicago and the Nation."

 BODY:
 GREAT FORTUNE
The Epic of Rockefeller Center.
By Daniel Okrent.
Illustrated. 512 pp. New York:
Viking. $29.95.
When Rockefeller Center's design was unveiled, Lewis Mumford, the urban planner and architecture critic, declared that it followed "the canons of Cloudcuckooland." Its decorative scheme was, he complained, "bad with an almost juvenile badness." If this misguided project was "the best our architects can do with freedom," Mumford fulminated, "they deserve to remain in chains." 
"They all laughed at Rockefeller Center," the Gershwin lyric goes, but the early reaction was nothing so benign. Newspapers overflowed with letters to the editor excoriating the complex as the "ugliest conglomeration of buildings in New York," and a "disgraceful symbol of a generation." One leading architect urged that it go up "as quickly as possible," because the sooner it was done "the sooner we shall be able to clear the ground and begin again." 
But before long, as Gershwin noted, they were "fighting to get in." And Rockefeller Center had established itself as one of the best-loved and most critically revered cityscapes in New York, or anywhere else. Today, its mere mention summons lush images of Manhattan at its swankest: late-night cocktails at the Rainbow Room; the Art Deco splendor of Radio City Music Hall.
How Rockefeller Center came to be, and its dramatic ascent in the popular imagination, are the subject of "Great Fortune," an absorbing, brightly written history by Daniel Okrent, who was a longtime top editor at Time Inc. Okrent delves into the history and pulls out an array of intriguing men, most of them little known, who have greater bragging rights to Rockefeller Center than the man whose name it bears. 
Ask a New Yorker which Rockefeller was responsible for Rockefeller Center, and the response will likely be John D. Rockefeller Sr., the great Standard Oil monopolist. But the family patriarch played no part in its creation, and may never even have visited. It was John D. Rockefeller Jr., known well into his adulthood as Junior, who took on the project and put up the money, in a Depression economy that left even him strapped for cash. 
Junior had a privileged childhood, as the son of the world's first billionaire, but one steeped in the flinty Baptist faith of his mother, Laura Celestia Spelman Rockefeller. "I am glad my son has told me what he wants for Christmas," Mrs. Rockefeller once said to a neighbor, "so now it can be denied him." While his father was the quintessential robber baron -- Ida Tarbell, the famed muckraker, detected in him "craftiness, cruelty and something indefinably repulsive" -- Junior was made of milder stuff. When the president of the Standard Oil Trust was caught up in a bribery scandal, Junior pronounced himself "sickened." He was deeply moved after visiting Ludlow, Colo., the site of the infamous Ludlow Massacre, in which 13 women and children were killed in antiunion violence at a Rockefeller-owned coal field. Partly, in Okrent's words, to "change the word 'Rockefeller' from the signifier of rapacious greed to a symbol of enlightened citizenship," Junior embarked on an energetic philanthropic career, building Riverside Church and what would later become Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, donating the land for the United Nations, and creating the Cloisters and Colonial Williamsburg. 
The idea for Rockefeller Center fell into Junior's lap, dropped there by the financier Otto Kahn, who wanted to build a new opera house. In time, the opera house would fall out of the planning, but Junior was enthusiastic about the idea of tearing down a stretch of speakeasies and rooming houses in midtown -- which, as it happened, neighbored on his own mansion -- and building something grander. He leased the land from Columbia University and hired John R. Todd, a wily, hard-driving developer (and grandfather of the former governor of New Jersey, Christine Todd Whitman), to make the dream a reality. 
From January 1929, when the Columbia lease was signed, to November 1939, when the U.S. Rubber building was officially completed, a colorful array of visionaries, artisans and schemers contributed to the undertaking. The book is at its best when it rescues these figures from obscurity. Charles O. Heydt, who started out as a 14-year-old office boy and rose to handle the Rockefellers' real estate transactions, extracted the land from Columbia on favorable terms. Ray Hood, a struggling architect who had recently won a competition to design the Chicago Tribune tower, drew up blueprints for the RCA Building and set the aesthetic tone for the whole complex. Donald Deskey, a modernist who went on to design the Crest toothpaste tube, was responsible for Radio City's opulent interiors. 
Rockefeller Center struggled in its early years, the worst of the Depression. It had an anchor tenant, the National Broadcasting Company, that lent the complex the name "Radio City," as well as undeniable cachet. But despite aggressive marketing and highly discounted rents, new lessees were hard to come by. To cut its losses, the Rockefeller family engaged in some strategic self-dealing: Standard Oil of New Jersey moved in, as did the Rockefeller Foundation. After World War II, as the national economy recovered, Rockefeller Center hit its stride. By April 1946, it had achieved the once unimaginable: a sizable waiting list. Before Rockefeller Center was finally sold off, it would become, in the assessment of family insiders, "by far the largest single repository" of Rockefeller wealth. 
Okrent has a good time with the most storied parts of Rockefeller Center lore. In his telling of the Diego Rivera mural fiasco, which ended with the radical artist's work in the RCA Building being destroyed, it was Frida Kahlo, Rivera's wife, who forced the showdown. Kahlo was the one, he suggests, who insisted on including touches like Lenin's head and upper-class women surrounded by gonorrhea and syphilis germs, and it was she (aided by Rivera's young assistant, Ben Shahn) who would not let them be removed. 
The history of the Rockettes appears in detail, as does the sad story of S. L. Rothafel, better known as Roxy, the larger-than-life impresario responsible for putting them on the Radio City stage. There are walk-ons by Gregory Peck and the writer and Trappist monk Thomas Merton, both of whom were briefly tour guides; Arturo Toscanini, who conducted the NBC Symphony from the famed Studio 8H; and Georgia O'Keeffe, who was bullied by her husband, the photographer Alfred Stieglitz, into giving up the chance to paint a massive mural. 
The humorist Fran Lebowitz has written that one problem with children is that they "will persist in discussing the color of a recently sighted cement mixer long after one's own interest in the topic has waned." So it often is with authors of books about building projects. Okrent's fascination is not with cement mixers, but with architectural planning and contractual arrangements. In the case of, say, the financial negotiations between Rockefeller and Columbia University less, as a noted architect said in another context, would be more.
A greater flaw is the book's failure to situate Rockefeller Center in a larger historical context, or to extract deeper meaning. It would be interesting to get more of Okrent's thoughts about the project's impact on the development of New York City. How important a role did it play in making Midtown Manhattan the center of world business it was to become? How influential was it on development in other cities? 
The book also has a light touch -- too light -- with the most unsettling parts of the story. Black employees were largely unwelcome at Rockefeller Center -- in the case of the Rockettes until as recently as 1987. Workers, represented by a toothless company union, were routinely mistreated. And the city was robbed of its fair share of this undertaking, since Junior, called by one critic New York's "Chief Tax Dolee," had a knack for keeping assessments low. Okrent notes all this in passing but, as his title suggests, he writes as a fan. The book ends by quoting a writer's sunny reflection that "Rockefeller Center begets a sauntering mood." It is an aesthetically justifiable, if not exactly earth-shattering, conclusion.
Of course, in an age when construction projects so often produce bland monstrosities, the ability to induce sauntering should not be discounted. Even Mumford was won over by Rockefeller Center in the end: he eventually pronounced it "a serene eyeful" and "the most exciting mass of buildings in the city." And generations of visitors, tourists and locals alike, have been moved to feel something like Gertrude Stein's modernist encomium: "The view of Rockefeller Center from Fifth Avenue is the most beautiful thing I have ever seen ever seen ever seen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Diego Rivera at work on his mural for Rockefeller Center in 1933, shortly before the offensive images were covered with tarpaper; in 1934 they were destroyed. (Photo by "Great Fortune")
