HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
F.D.A. ponders pros and cons of the ways prescription drugs are promoted to consumers.

BYLINE:  By Nat Ives 

 BODY:
AN ad for the prescription drug Zoloft asks: "Feeling sad? Anxious? Tired?" Zoloft is sold by Pfizer as a treatment for depression and other disorders. It is but one of many print and broadcast advertisements that pitch prescription drugs directly to consumers -- a category of ads scrutinized last week at a hearing held by the Food and Drug Administration. 
 The two-day hearing, in Washington, was part of the agency's review of the rules governing prescription-drug advertising. Because many of the 29 studies presented at the hearing reported positive public results -- like increased communication between patients and doctors -- the prevailing prediction among supporters of the ads was that the drug agency would allow the ads to continue in much the same form as today. 
 "It's rare that you get such validation from a meeting like this," said Dick O'Brien, executive vice president and director for government affairs at the American Association of Advertising Agencies, a longtime advocate for the ads. "This is one where you feel all of a sudden like you're on the side of angels."
"My hope is that these two days were so positive that they may help to put this controversy to bed once and for all."
Even critics were not optimistic that the agency would make significant changes. They said the event, at which research was presented by attendees from Pfizer to Time Inc. to the Mayo Clinic, told just part of the story. Calls for change continued from critics like Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination.
"Senator Edwards thinks it's misleading for an ad to show a woman running through a field while the fine print says 'may cause serious side effects,"' said Michael Briggs, the senator's press secretary. "The F.D.A. should require drug manufacturers to provide fair and balanced information about a drug's risks as well as the potential benefits."
Meanwhile, though, the ads are the darlings of broadcasting and publishing executives. Even in an uncertain economic climate, spending in the prescription-drug category totaled more than $2.5 billion last year, up from nearly $1.6 billion in 1999, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres.
More than just revenue, magazine executives said, the ads even give readers another reason to buy their publications. 
"Both the advertising and the editorial product provide information, and that presents a benefit to the reader," said Ellen Oppenheim, executive vice president and chief marketing officer at the Magazine Publishers of America. Even some F.D.A. officials said the meeting showed that the ads can also have public health benefits.
"It's been an incredible sea change, from 'Is it a good thing?' to 'This is a good thing, and how can we make it better?"' said Peter J. Pitts, the drug agency's associate commissioner for external relations. 
Making it better might mean communicating risks more effectively, he said: "That's exactly what we're studying now. We're going to try to reach our own judgment on what would be the best path forward." The agency expects to propose any rule changes by the end of the year.
At Pfizer, executives said few if any changes were necessary. "We feel that the regulations are working the way they are," said Dorothy Wetzel, the company's vice president for United States consumer marketing of pharmaceuticals.
"My hope is that whatever comes out of the meeting really advances our ability as an industry to effectively communicate with consumers," she said. "It would be a shame if what comes out makes it more complicated and confusing."
But some critics showed no sign of backing off.
"This is a really unlevel playing field for consumers," said Larry D. Sasich, a research analyst at the health research group of Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group. "You have an industry that maintains that a 30-second or 60-second television spot empowers consumers to make an informed decision about their drug therapy." 
Instead, Mr. Sasich said, the spots play up the promise of the products, leaving consumers on their own to ferret out potential side effects or adverse reactions.
The Washington meeting did not adequately address such issues, said Barbara Mintzes, a post-doctoral fellow at the Center for Health Services and Policy Research at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver.
"The question is: Who was talking?" Ms. Mintzes said. "There were a few people presenting who were independent, but the large majority were either people from the industry or financed by them."
Anyone was welcome to present original research at the meeting, but an open door does nothing to ensure that all the relevent research is included, Ms. Mintzes said.
Linda Golodner, president at the National Consumers League, another nonprofit advocacy group, said that the meeting generally showed that consumers were using the information from ads as a springboard to seek more information. "They are not necessarily demanding the drug, but they want to see if that drug is right for them."
The problem with the ads, Ms. Golodner said, is that in many cases information on effectiveness and potential side effects is too hard to find, in contrast with the marketing claims being made about benefits.
"When risk information is given, an upset stomach is sort of given the same equality of liver damage," she said.
The Consumers League is pushing for rules requiring print ads to include a box summarizing all that information, similar to the nutrition box on packaged food.
But the Consumers League agreed with Ms. Mintzes and Public Citizen that the biggest improvement would be additional money for monitoring of the ads and greater power to punish violators.
Mr. Pitts, the drug agency commissioner, said that the agency constantly reviewed ads and was getting better at it.

HEADLINE: China Censors a Senator 

BYLINE:  By Ross Terrill; Ross Terrill, a research associate at Harvard's Fairbank Center for East Asian Research, is author of "The New Chinese Empire."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Hillary Clinton has good reason to be "amazed and outraged" that the Chinese edition of her biography "Living History" omits her criticisms of Beijing's repressive regime. After all, President Bill Clinton, shortly before the couple went to China in 1998, said that "the shackles of state socialism once choked off enterprise" but the country was "moving to join the thriving community of free democracies." Unhappily, although many top Democrats and Republicans still see economics as destiny for the People's Republic, getting rich and becoming free are not cause and effect.
 The passages in "Living History" about the 19 years that the dissident Harry Wu spent as a political prisoner disappear in the officially licensed Yilin Press translation, which has sold more than 200,000 copies in just a month. Gone too, in violation of Senator Clinton's book contract, is her sympathy for the students in the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests and her account of Tibetan activists banned from a United Nations conference on women near Beijing in 1995. She was correct to attend that conference -- against the advice of Mr. Wu, Representative Nancy Pelosi and others who felt boycotting it would have made a more effective statement -- and she spoke boldly there. 
 Yet Beijing seems to be getting the last laugh. Chinese readers will undoubtedly believe the book's accounts of her 1995 and 1998 trips to China, but they are being lied to. Even if they are aware the book has been edited by the thought police, they are in the position of not knowing what "anti-China" sentences have been excised, which is almost worse than having no book in their hands at all.
Senator Clinton is the latest in a long line of victimized authors. In the 1980's my biography of Mao's wife, Jiang Qing, was published in Beijing -- without contract or permission -- with all the positive references to her cut out. In the bowdlerized version, Jiang Qing appeared responsible for all Mao's failings. Since then China's government-controlled publishing houses have seemed to improve, particularly after Beijing signed the Bern Copyright Convention in 1992 and joined the World Trade Organization in 2001. 
Yet the "Living History" episode suggests backsliding. We're talking about a United States senator here, and the tampering with "Living History" is so blatant that the Chinese must have known she would find out. Here is the nub of the issue: foreign opinion, even that of the Clintons, is less important to Beijing than keeping its grip over the minds of its citizens. China's post-Mao openness to the world, an economic strategy, remains contradicted by its fear of a free flow of non-economic information reaching the ears and eyes of the people. Citizens of the People's Republic are trusted with their money but not their minds. 
A fashionable phrase in academic and foreign policy circles holds that today's China is "a normal country." Its Leninist state somehow slipped away in the middle of the night, and the Communist Party's new agenda is simply to free up markets and bless commerce. But this is nonsense: ultimately, it is impossible to separate economic freedom and political freedom. China's progress, economic and political, will be held back if censorship and condescension to the populace continue. Leninism cannot indefinitely be propped up by consumerism.
In 1990, 14 years after Mao's death, I found my way to a government-planned (but unpublicized) exhibition on AIDS in a gray-walled building near Tiananmen Square. There were pictures of dirty toilet seats, promiscuous American soldiers, gays frolicking in San Francisco. The Chinese captions said Western bourgeois society had spawned a new and terrible disease. 
Yet soon AIDS became a major problem in China, and not just in Shanghai and Beijing, where the government could blame "decadent" Western tourists for seducing Chinese youth, but in the poppy-growing country of southwest China. In rural China, blood-selling and drug use caused the disease to spread in frightening ways. Beijing's instincts over AIDS were similar to those over SARS and, now, "Living History": weed out awkward truths and spur the Chinese people to patriotism. 
So a literary trick reveals the dictatorial dragon's teeth. Worldwide, neither a truly free press nor a privatized economy has ever appeared while a Communist Party held on to power. There are two implications for China policy. One is that the United States won't get reciprocity in cultural and professional exchanges or in market access until political freedom comes to the Chinese people. 
The other implication concerns China's future. Will the People's Republic become strong enough to replace the United States as No. 1 in the world? Or will it collapse from the strains of going down one road in economics and a different one in politics? My feeling is that a power formidable enough to eclipse America would need global moral authority as well as skyscrapers, missiles and patriotism. 
For the average Chinese, the arbitrariness that mauled Hillary Clinton's memoir is a daily occurrence. They learn to self-censor. "To get rich is glorious," Deng Xiaoping rasped with pride -- but to become well informed can be hazardous.
Turning the current of information on and off in a complex society of 1.3 billion people, if managedintelligently, may preserve the party-state for a time. But the government risks its credibility issuing a diktat demarcating "pro-China" from "anti-China." Lies diminish the liar. Beijing may find that deception from above threatens stability no less than criticism from below.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
In Handling Innovation, Patience Is a Virtue

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 25 

 BODY:
In one of its current television commercials, the Hewlett-Packard Company describes itself as a leader in the science of nanotechnology. It invites consumers to imagine the exciting products of the future, like light bulbs that never burn out and "a cellphone so small an ant could use it."
 The advertising team probably did not run that one by R. Stanley Williams, who works in the nanotechnology trenches as director for quantum science research at Hewlett-Packard Labs in Palo Alto, Calif. Not surprisingly, Mr. Williams chose not to elaborate on the telecommunications needs of insects when he spoke here this week at the Emerging Technologies Conference at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Instead, he preached patience. Yes, it is possible to build a hand-held device that can outperform all the earth's present computers, he said, but it may take 50 years to figure out how to make it. 
 He warned that consumers will get fed up with innovations -- including the wonders expected from nanotechnology, or the science of very tiny objects -- that are oversold or underdelivered.
"They are a little bit jaded," Mr. Williams said. "They've heard too much of this wonderful future, and they wonder why it isn't here right now." 
Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of the General Electric Company, also counseled patience, to engineers and investors. He has poured extra money into research and development at G.E. while loosening timelines on projects that may not pay off for 10 years or more. For established companies, he said, investing in emerging technologies is a matter of survival. 
"I just see very clearly that unless you're out there pushing the envelope and driving innovation, you're not going to get the kind of margins and the kind of growth that we need for a company like G.E.," Mr. Immelt said. "I really see it as an economic imperative."
Some experts warn that even the best corporate research efforts may not be enough to ward off disruptions to their businesses that come from innovations out of left field. Inevitably, some of today's household names will falter in the face of newcomers with better ideas, just as several mainframe computer companies were left behind in the wake of minicomputers and minicomputer companies disappeared with the advent of PC's.
Nathan Myhrvold, a former top scientist at the Microsoft Corporation who runs Intellectual Ventures, an investment firm in Bellevue, Wash., surmised that in the not-too-distant future, the top 20 companies in pharmaceuticals, with the exception of one or two, would be unfamiliar names. 
"If you look at the pipeline of drugs in clinical trials," he said, "way more of them were made by the little companies than the big guys." 
The conference, organized by M.I.T.'s Technology Review magazine, drew about 1,000 attendees from established companies like Cisco Systems Inc., Kraft Foods Inc. and the Sprint Corporation, and even a few unknown start-ups. 
They listened to colorful descriptions of nanotechnology as well as other innovations like developing hydrogen fuel sources and creating medicines based on genomics. Wireless technologies seemed among the ripest for products making their way onto the market, as demonstrated by four-year-old WideRay, a San Francisco company that was showing off the wireless capabilities of its proximity server, which allows a user to download information onto a personal digital assistant just by moving near it. 
Despite the promise of these inventions, several speakers were fretful. Faced with a sluggish economy, many companies have reined in their research and development budgets.
David Tennenhouse, vice president of the Intel Corporation's technology group, more than once lamented the insufficiency of government financing for basic research at universities. And Edward B. Roberts, a professor of technology management at M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management, pointed out that two-thirds of all corporate research and development expenditures are for short-term projects, not the long-term ones that will be the ground-shaking breakthroughs.
At the General Motors Corporation, research spending has stayed about the same in recent years, but Lawrence F. Burns, vice president for research and development and planning, said he has achieved better results by working with knowledgeable (and less expensive) researchers in China, India, Israel and Russia. Sharing is also a virtue, as in the research lab G.M. owns with the Boeing Company and the Raytheon Company. 
"Each company has specific directive research and then shared research," Mr. Burns said. "That's a highly leverage-able thing." 
Lucien P. Hughes, research director for the technology labs at Accenture, the consulting company, agreed that alliances in research are now the norm.
"The days of the large-scale insular lab -- not talking to the rest of the world -- I think are over for now," he said.
Finding the technology -- either through internal ingenuity, outsourcing or acquisition -- is only the beginning. For a time-honored company, breakthrough technologies can be as disruptive inside the company as they are externally. Too many companies are not structurally prepared to handle them, said Professor Roberts of M.I.T.
"It's not all a question of a willingness to spend," he said. "It's a willingness to participate."
Moreover, while many companies are trying to tie their research efforts more closely to their actual marketing needs, some of the most successful companies have faltered along the way by listening too closely to what their current customers want, and not planning for unknown markets. 
"I do a lot of customer interaction," Mr. Immelt of G.E. said, "but when it comes time to figure out nanotechnology, there's no customer view on nanotechnology."
As for whether old-school or upstart companies will dominate the innovation game in the coming years, Mr. Myhrvold of Intellectual Ventures said it is anyone's guess. 
"Really radical stuff," he said, "is going to come bubbling up from random sources, like it always does."

HEADLINE: New Museum Joins Forces With Artists' Web Site 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW MIRAPAUL 

 BODY:
In an unusual instance of an established cultural organization taking an upstart arts group under its wing, the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo is forging a partnership with Rhizome.org, an Internet site where digital artists can exhibit their online projects and crow about their status as art-world outsiders.
 In an arrangement announced last week, Rhizome will become officially affiliated with the New Museum. Rhizome's staff has already moved into the New Museum's offices at 583 Broadway, between Houston and Prince Streets, and the museum will provide Rhizome with accounting, clerical and other administrative services. The partnership will allow Rhizome to expand its activities and audience while giving the New Museum's curators access to a fresh crop of emerging artists. 
 Lisa Phillips, the New Museum's director, said, "Our audience and Rhizome's audience will have the potential to cross over and know more about each other."
In its last fiscal year Rhizome spent about $323,000. Ms. Phillips said the affiliation would reduce Rhizome's expenses in the current year by more than $100,000.
But a digital-arts group and a museum, no matter how progressively minded, can make strange bedfellows. When digital artists began to create online artworks in the mid-1990's, much of the art form's energy was derived from the notion that the works did not need museums or galleries to reach an audience. Spawned by that sensibility in 1996, Rhizome quickly became one of the most popular Internet sites devoted to the digital arts. It is an online-only meeting place where members can announce new artworks, request technical assistance or argue over obscure aesthetic issues.
As excitement about digital art spread, museums began to commission online artworks. After the dot-com boom went bust, though, museum interest cooled along with the economy. The Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, for instance, dismissed its new-media curator earlier this year.
As a result it is not clear whether the New Museum-Rhizome partnership can be viewed as a step in extracting Internet art from its tiny niche or as a life preserver for a floundering art form. Tim Whidden, a digital artist in Brooklyn and a longtime Rhizome contributor, said, "I'm wondering if it means a strengthening of new media, that is, it's being taken out of its ghetto and put into a larger art-world context, or a weakening, that is, it can't stand on its own legs."

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW; 
The Scrimmage of Old and New

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
The new football stadium at Soldier Field in Chicago is an uncannily accurate portrait of a great American city in changing times. Some Chicago lovers find the portrait less than flattering. Even before the inaugural game last night, the Chicago Bears' new home has been harshly criticized for (among other things) destroying the old landmark stadium that the design has transformed.
 I suspect that it won't be long before the city embraces the new field. The design's urban and architectural merits are considerable. Its conceptual qualities are better still. If you set out to write something bad about the design, you ultimately end up with a critique of the society that produced it. But the design is much more than a symptom of our time. It is a creative response to it. Soldier Field is a daring study of urban America in extremis, precariously poised for a future beyond its widely unlamented demise. 
 Designed by Ben Wood of Chicago and Carlos Zapata of Boston, the 62,200-seat stadium stretches the concept of adaptive reuse nearly past the breaking point. Retaining the classical shell of a stadium designed in the 1920's, the architects have inserted what amounts to an entirely new structure. Instead of matching the two parts in style, they have updated the old stadium in terms of spirit. The result is a major breakthrough: the liberation of sports architecture from sports architects. 
If you want to build a great stadium, hire a real architect. Cities in Europe, Asia and Latin America have understood this for years. In the United States sports architecture has been crippled by the same developer mentality that has hampered almost every type of building except museums and concert halls. Make it exciting! But don't risk surprises. Don't hire anyone who hasn't done the same thing at least 2,000 times.
This Catch-22 has given us 10 years of mediocre sports architecture, much of it in the retro mode typified by Coors Field in Denver. It has been riveting to watch baby-boom fathers inflict their traumatized inner childhoods on their own unsuspecting progeny in turn. But for cities the loss has been great. Just when our urban centers might have been aiming to surpass our overseas counterparts in creative ambition, our teams were settling for the architectural equivalent of stale popcorn and warm beer.
Soldier Field, by contrast, is easily a match for the most advanced stadium design anywhere in the world today. The $382.5 million building, part of a broader plan to improve Chicago's lakeside parks, should be a model for cities that are looking toward architecture to strengthen their identities as contemporary cultural centers.
The original Soldier Field was a concrete structure in Doric style, reflecting the classical motif of Chicago's lakefront parks. Designed by Holabird & Root in 1919-22 as a memorial to those killed in World War I, the stadium was originally intended for track and field events. Even after successive remodelings, the sightlines for football were far from ideal.
The decision in the early 1990's to rebuild the stadium was part of a movement away from the existing practice of putting sports arenas in suburban areas accessible only by car. Retaining the downtown location made perfect sense for Chicago, a great walkers' town. Preserving the perimeter colonnades from the old stadium was also a sound decision, and one of impeccable classical pedigree. In Rome the reuse of ancient theaters and stadiums has long been integral to the reweaving of the urban fabric.
But the artistic pairing of old and new is distinctly contemporary. Additions to older structures are a defining building type of our time. The type is the product of a collision between two forces: the impulse to preserve and the need for economic development. 
Chicago has dealt with this conflict better than most cities, nowhere more emphatically than in the new stadium's design.
I call this type of design parabuilding: it is the modern tick on the postmodern host. New York examples include the Palace Hotel, a modern shaft that towers above the historic Vuillard Houses on Madison Avenue and 51st Street. Typically, as at the Palace, the parabuilding is designed as a discreet background to the existing host. Not at Soldier Field. Here modernity erupts with the jubilance of a prodigal returned. It's happy to be home.
This is a place of extremities held in a dynamic state of imbalance. The tension between tradition and contemporaneity is but one source for this highly energized design. Perhaps the most startling of these derives from the juxtaposition of the stadium's classically symmetrical shell and the whirling asymmetry of the new building within it. This is a place made for movement: sky boxes and open seating are arranged in what look like tectonic plates that have been subjected to the forces of a centrifuge.
Extreme cantilevering makes this composition possible. This technique is theatrically demonstrated in the long, tapering trusses that streak through the air like comet trails at either end of the field. Functionally justified as armatures for two electronic signboards, these elongated forms are emblematic in themselves: symbols of grace under pressure.
Cantilevering is also used to give the banks of seating a steep rake. Besides bringing the seats closer to the playing field, the steep angle creates an impression of verticality. This effect plays off the horizontal stretch of the grandstands. And so it may occur to you that the field has become the central plaza of a European town, the site of some great civic ritual viewed from the packed windows of surrounding buildings.
The skyboxes -- here called executive suites -- add to this impression. These glassed-in luxury accommodations are housed on four levels in what amounts to a separate building. Stretching around the field's east sideline, they give the effect of a glass office building just outside the lower structures ringing the plaza.
This impression links the stadium to views of the Chicago skyline made possible by deep cuts through the structure at the end zones. A result is extreme intimacy: with the field, the city and Chicago's heroic tradition of leadership in the building arts.
A separate building for rich people! A defiled historic landmark! A prime lakesidelocation instead of some depressed neighborhood on the outskirts that might have benefited from this enormous urban investment! Extreme intimacy, my foot! More like an extreme example of big bucks getting their way!
Well, all right, if you insist. Yet implicit in such criticisms is the assumption that the city should somehow operate outside the economic system we have developed for ourselves in the post-cold-war world. Perhaps it should. Until that dubious prospect is realized, however, we shouldn't expect our architects to do more than aestheticize the actual urban condition.
Our cities are becoming more, not less, dependent on spectacles and pastimes. One spectacle is the historic fabric of the city itself. But only theme parks can become museums of themselves. New buildings interpret the changing life of the contemporary city to its living inhabitants.
Sports is big business. If you don't like seeing the name Cadillac on the clubhouse for the luxury suites at Soldier Field, try Wrigley Field. At Soldier Field the pressures coursing through the modern city are made visible. 
If your commitment is to classicism, you will find a more authentically classical urbanism in the recast stadium than was present when the concrete colonnades stood alone. And if your commitment is to conflict, as a city lover's ought always to be, the field's controversial reception will not let you down.

 CORRECTION:
An architecture review on Tuesday about the new football stadium at Soldier Field in Chicago misidentified the headquarters city for one designer, Ben Wood; it is Boston, where he is a partner with the other designer, Carlos Zapata -- not Chicago. The review also misstated the timing of the decision to rebuild the original stadium. It was in 1998, not the early 1990's.
An architecture review on Tuesday about the new football stadium at Soldier Field in Chicago misstated the name of the firm that designed the original stadium. While it is now called Holabird & Root, it was then Holabird & Roche.
An architecture review on Sept. 30 about the new football stadium at Soldier Field in Chicago misspelled the name of the historic Manhattan houses that adjoin the modern Palace Hotel the way the classical shell of the old football stadium meets the modern design of the new one. They are the Villard Houses, not Vuillard.

HEADLINE: AN APPRECIATION; 
Method Man: Kazan's Landscape of Desire

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT 

 BODY:
Movie directors are known for being vain, autocratic and egomaniacal, but the curious nature of their art form also makes them invisible. Their own powerful personalities most often find expression in the faces and gestures of others. Think of John Ford, for example, and the picture you see in your head will probably be of John Wayne. Elia Kazan, who could be as passionate, difficult and dictatorial as any of his peers, will live on primarily through the images of a handful of actors. 
 The television obituaries that followed Mr. Kazan's death on Sunday were like an anthology of great moments in method acting. There was Marlon Brando, in "A Streetcar Named Desire" and "On The Waterfront," screaming, "Stella!" and whispering to Rod Steiger that he could have been a contender. There was James Dean in "East of Eden" and Warren Beatty in "Splendor in the Grass," beautiful young men suffering beautifully; there were Eli Wallach and Karl Malden in "Baby Doll," playing out their Mississippi snake dance of sexual and economic rivalry. 
 Mr. Kazan was a founder of the Actors Studio, and in the late 1940's he frequently shuttled between Broadway and Hollywood. He was, perhaps more than anyone else, responsible for bringing the sensibilities of American theatrical realism and the style of acting it spawned into American movies. The stylized speech and decorous movements of an earlier era gave way to stuttering, smoldering displays of emotion. Social problems, sexual subtexts and psychological truth became the hallmarks of seriousness on stage and screen. 
Realism, in any art form, and perhaps especially on film,where the illusion of transparency is greatest, is a notoriously tricky term. Mr. Kazan's movies, seen today, are likely to seem less slices of life than social and psychological fables, more rhetorical and high-minded than tough and unvarnished. Which is what they always were of course, and why they stay with us. They are parables of conflicted conscience and unstable desire, studies of individuals -- of men, to be precise -- driven to rage, rebellion and sometimes to do the right thing. Nobody is really like Stanley Kowalski, or like Lonesome Rhodes, the backwoods media demagogue played by Andy Griffith in "A Face in the Crowd." Even the actual Emiliano Zapata was not much like Mr. Brando in "Viva, Zapata!" But sometimes we like our realism to be larger than life.
Critical appraisals of Mr. Kazan before his death tended to be grudging: he occupies at best the second tier of the auteurist pantheon, applauded for his work with actors but denied the laurels retrospectively granted to directors like his friend and contemporary Nicholas Ray. 
This is partly because Mr. Kazan's films, unlike Ray's, were readily embraced and easily understood when they came out. Their popularity with audiences and Oscar voters, their earnest engagement with serious contemporary themes, their sometimes pious liberalism make movies like "Gentleman's Agreement," "Pinkie" and even "On The Waterfront" look to some eyes hopelessly middlebrow. 
Mary McCarthy, who from her perch at Partisan Review was the most intransigent critic of American dramatic realism in the 1940's and 50's, summed up these objections: "Today most intellectuals have seen at least one play by Williams, Inge and Miller, and at least one movie directed by Kazan. Their opinion, so far as I can tell, remains about the same as when they did not have the price of a ticket: they think this theater is corn."
She was not entirely wrong. Mr. Kazan's realism, like that of Arthur Miller (whose plays he directed on Broadway) and John Steinbeck (who collaborated with Mr. Kazan on "Viva, Zapata!" and "East of Eden") did have its corny aspect. But though it offended some refined palates, that grain also provided some honest nourishment. 
It is easy now to cringe at the didacticism of "Gentleman's Agreement," in which Gregory Peck pretends to be a Jew (and is actually believed to be one) to expose and denounce anti-Semitism. But in 1947 the point needed making, and in a way that a mass audience might be prepared to hear. "Pinky," the story of a pale-skinned black woman passing for white, may seem stilted and melodramatic today, but in 1949 its agonized humanism was downright radical. The impact of movies like these on American attitudes about race and ethnicity after World War II should not be underestimated.
Those movies have faded into history, but Mr. Kazan's work from the 50's retains a great deal of vitality, and not only because of Brando and Dean. Along with his movies, and perhaps at their expense, Mr. Kazan is remembered for his role in the ideological melodrama of the McCarthy era. He is recalled both as a hero of liberal Hollywood in its golden age and as a scoundrel in a time of political treachery. 
Did he, as his detractors claim, betray his principles by giving names to anti-Communist inquisitors? Or was he, as he insisted, trying to live up to them? There is no use trying to settle the argument, or to resolve the contradictions that define Mr. Kazan's career, and are what his movies are all about.

HEADLINE: The Gold in Baseball's Diamond 

BYLINE:  By Andrew Zimbalist; Andrew Zimbalist, professor of economics at Smith College, is author of "May the Best Team Win: Baseball Economics and Public Policy."

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass. 

 BODY:
As this season drew to a close, remarkably half of baseball's teams had a chance to make the playoffs. Has Major League Baseball's year-old collective bargaining agreement, with its revenue-sharing plan and luxury tax, leveled the playing field? Not exactly.
 The tight races were chance occurences -- the result of a muddle of mediocrity at the top of the American League's Central Division and in the battle for the National League's wild card slot. They had nothing to do with greater parity among the teams. 
 If the changes in the collective bargaining agreement were having their intended effect, the payrolls of the top teams would be falling and those for the bottom teams would be rising. But this isn't happening. The standard deviation, or the dispersion, of opening-day payrolls actually rose to $27.3 million in 2003 from $24.7 million in 2002, an increase of 10.5 percent.
Viewed differently, of the 15 teams in contention in mid-September, 10 were among the top 12 teams in payroll. Only two (the Oakland Athletics and the Kansas City Royals) came from the bottom 10 teams in payroll.
So why is the new collective bargaining agreement not working? Put simply, the agreement taxes increased earnings of low-revenue clubs at around 45 percent. Every time a relatively poor team like the Milwaukee Brewers increases its revenues by a dollar, the league gives the club 45 cents less in revenue-sharing money. The team thus has little incentive to use its revenue-sharing money to buy better players and improve itself.
But wait, you say, doesn't the new agreement require teams that receive revenue-sharing money to meet a minimum payroll standard? No. Rather it sets out a vague criterion: a team must use its transfers "to improve its performance on the field." According to this standard, then, Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner and the person charged with enforcing this provision, could conclude that a team that pays off its debt or increases executive pay is taking steps to improve itself. In fact, almost any action could be justified as potentially improving the team.
Interestingly, the team owned by Mr. Selig's family, the Brewers, is faring pretty well under the new system. According to league estimates, the Brewers will receive a larger increase in revenue-sharing money than any other team, with receipts growing to an estimated $8.2 million in 2003 from roughly $1.2 million in 2001. (This is because Mr. Selig insisted on a revenue-sharing system that taxed the top teams most heavily and benefited the lower middle, rather than the bottom, teams the most.) 
But are the Brewers improving themselves by signing better players? Well, the team's opening-day payroll fell to $40.6 million this year from $50.3 million last year. 
Of course, the Brewers are not alone. Other teams benefited from increased revenue sharing -- and also cut their payrolls. Transfers for the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, for example, grew by $5.1 million, yet the team's opening-day payroll fell to $19.6 million this year from $34.4 million in 2002.
Baseball's competitive balance problem is mostly a problem of bottom-dwelling teams performing poorly year after year. If these teams don't have the economic incentive or the statutory compulsion to raise their payrolls or invest more in their farm systems, then they will remain uncompetitive. The game will go on -- but nothing will change.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Shares Rise asInvestors Capitalize on Last Week's Slump

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks climbed yesterday as investors scooped up shares beaten down in last week's slump and fund managers spruced up portfolios for the end of the quarter. 
 Today is the last day of the third quarter, and there could be swings in the stock market as money managers dress up their portfolios by dropping the losers and adding the winners. 
 Stocks fell sharply last week amid jitters over rising oil prices and a drop in the dollar after a statement from the Group of 7 economic powers. 
"Last week's G-7 stuff was the impetus for selling into the end of the week, but right now, the market seems to be shrugging all that off," said James Park, trader at Brean Murray & Company. 
The Nasdaq composite index rose 32.49 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,824.56, while the Dow Jones industrial average gained 67.16 points, or 0.7 percent, to 9,380.24. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 9.73 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 1,006.58. 
Trading volume was moderate as investors questioned whether the economic recovery was healthy enough to support the market's run-up over the last six months. Hefty gains so far this year have ignited worries that share prices may have risen too far, too fast.
The Nasdaq skidded nearly 6 percent last week to its biggest weekly loss since April 2002. 
Intel rose $1.10, or 4 percent, to $28.37. Global chip sales increased to $13.42 billion in August, up 4 percent from July, according to the World Semiconductor Trade Statistics organization, keeping the hard-hit industry on track for a healthy recovery. 
Nokia jumped 64 cents, or 4 percent, to $15.90. Investors have shunned the company, the leading cellphone maker, leaving it one of the cheapest technology stocks around, but they may be overlooking some changes in the business that could bring a new round of growth, according to an article over the weekend in Barron's. 
The life insurer John Hancock Financial Services fell 48 cents, to $33.82, after rallying on Friday. Manulife Financial of Canada agreed on Sunday to buy John Hancock for about $11 billion. Manulife fell $1.02, to $29.18, in the United States.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

Treasury Notes Plunge
(By Bloomberg News) -- The benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell yesterday, with the yield posting its biggest one-day gain in almost four weeks in New York trading, after a government report showed that consumer spending increased by 0.8 percent in August.
The note is headed for its first quarterly loss since the end of 2002 as analysts predict that the economy expanded at a 4.5 percent annual rate this quarter, according to the median estimate of 59 economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. The economy grew 3.3 percent in the second quarter.
"We just don't see a lot of compelling value right now in the Treasury market," said Michael Mullaney, who helps manage $10 billion in stocks and bonds at the Fiduciary Trust Company in Boston.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 22/32, to a price of 101 11/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.08 percent from 4 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 16/32, to 105 13/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.01 percent from 4.93 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES; 
Speculation on Weaker Dollar Leads to Gains for Euro and Yen

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against the euro and the yen in New York trading yesterday, on speculation that United States officials might seek a weaker currency to bolster corporate profits and extend a recovery. 
 The dollar fell against 15 of the 16 most widely traded currencies, weakening 1 percent against the euro and declining to its lowest level against the yen since December 2000. 
A government report on Friday will probably show the economy shed jobs for the eighth consecutive month in September, according to the median forecast of 64 economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. 
 Paul Podolsky, currency strategist at the FleetBoston Financial Corporation, said the declining payrolls would "raise questions about the sustainability of consumer demand," and might lead officials to "talk down the dollar even more" to bolster growth through exports.
The dollar erased its gains in midmorning trading and weakened to $1.1589 for a euro by 4 p.m. in New York, from $1.1474 on Friday. The dollar ranged from $1.1398 to $1.1601 a euro, its weakest since July 1. Against Japan's currency, the dollar fell to 110.91 yen from 111.91 Friday. It reached 110.73 yen earlier. 
The Treasury Department said there was no change in the administration's strong-dollar policy. Robert Nichols, the Treasury's assistant secretary for public affairs, told reporters, "We are not going to respond to every goofy market rumor on currencies." 
Enrico Caruso, chief currency trader at Tempest Asset Management in Tustin, Calif., said gains in the euro accelerated after its value rose above $1.1550 a dollar, a level where many traders who were betting against the currency had placed orders to cut their losses, forcing them to buy the euro.

HEADLINE: Deal to Acquire U.S. Insurer Is Part of a Canadian Trend 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 29 

 BODY:
By proposing to acquire John Hancock Financial Services, Manulife Financial has joined a growing group of Canadian financial institutions that have come to view expansion in the United States as one of the most critical drivers of their growth.
 "If you look at the size of the Canadian economy and the Canadian population, it's clear that to achieve your goals you have to be present in markets other than your own," Dominic D'Alessandro, Manulife's chief executive, said today. 
 The John Hancock deal, valued at $11 billion in Manulife stock, would create a life insurer that manages $246 billion in assets. Measured by market value, the combination would be the second-biggest company listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. 
Several Canadian banks and insurance companies already have a big presence in the United States. The banks, barred by the Canadian government from merging among themselves, have spent about 13 billion Canadian dollars since 1996 on acquisitions in the United States.
For example, the Toronto-Dominion Bank owns the TD Waterhouse discount brokerage firm, while Sun Life Financial of Toronto controls MFS Investment Management of Boston, a large mutual fund distributor. Sun Life paid $2.6 billion two years ago for Keyport Life, also of Boston, which specializes in annuities. The Bank of Montreal has controlled Harris Bank, based in Chicago, since the mid-1980's.
Michael Overvelde, an analyst at UBS Securities in Toronto, said he expected the pace of such deals to pick up. "If opportunities are limited in Canada, the United States makes the most obvious sense, not only because of its proximity but because Canadian banks have operations there to leverage from," he said.
Over the last three years, the Royal Bank of Canada, the country's biggest financial institution, has completed 10 acquisitions in the United States, mostly in North Carolina and Florida. Its American operations contributed 27 percent of revenue and 13 percent of net income in the nine months to July 31, up from 7 percent and 3 percent in 2000. 
Royal Bank's travel insurance arm said last week that it would start offering policies through travel agents in 34 American states. 
Toronto-Dominion Bank is shifting its emphasis from corporate to retail banking, and Mr. Overvelde said that the bank was most likely to expand its retail business through acquisitions in the United States. The Bank of Nova Scotia has also indicated that it is looking for suitable targets in the United States.
Manulife's American operations contributed 34 percent of its earnings last year. In getting John Hancock, Manulife would gain a well-known brand as well as greatly broaden its product range and strengthen its sales force. According to A. M. Best, the insurance-rating group, "the combined organization will possess significant scale and share in every market in which it operates."
John Hancock's chief executive, David D'Alessandro, has often said that the company needed to seek a merger partner to gain enough scale to compete effectively against the likes of MetLife and Prudential Financial. 
Mr. D'Alessandro told analysts today that the deal would also fulfill John Hancock's need "to rebalance our risk portfolio."
Using 2002 data, the proportion of earnings from relatively risky guaranteed and structured financial products would drop to 6 percent from 16 percent. This business mostly comprises 401(k) retirement plans that offer a return guaranteed by insurance companies. The companies need to cover that return through other investments.
Under terms of the deal, John Hancock shareholders will receive 1.1853 shares of Manulife for each John Hancock share, worth $37.60 a share, a 9.6 percent premium over the closing price on Friday.
Shares of John Hancock jumped sharply late last week amid speculation of a pending sale. A Manulife official said that the financial terms were reached last Wednesday but that an announcement had been withheld pending various regulatory approvals. Manulife shares closed at 39.41 Canadian dollars on the Toronto Stock Exchange today, down 1.44 Canadian dollars. Shares of John Hancock fell 48 cents, to $33.82.
The combined company's head office will be in Toronto but its North American operations will be based in Boston. Dominic D'Alessandro, 56, will be the president and chief executive. David D'Alessandro, 52, will initially be chief operating officer and will take on the additional title of president a year after the transaction is completed. 
The two D'Alessandros are not related but say they have ancestors who lived within a few hundred miles of one another in Italy. David D'Alessandro said today that "I expect to be running this company for a long time, working for Dominic."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dominic D'Alessandro, Manulife's chief executive, right, and David D'Alessandro, John Hancock's chief, at a news conference yesterday. (Photo by Canadian Press)

HEADLINE: As Nassau Attends to Finances, Its Credit Rating Could Rise Again 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Sept. 29 

 BODY:
Nassau County government, until recently a symbol of fiscal mismanagement, was notified today that its bond rating is in line to be upgraded for the second time this year.
 Nassau's turnaround runs counter to the trend of many other local governments, whose bond ratings have been hurt by the economic slump. 
 Moody's Investors Service already upgraded Nassau this year, as did other rating services. The upgrade was the county's first in 15 years. 
Today, citing "significant progress" in Nassau's fiscal recovery, Moody's again placed the county on its "watch list for a potential upgrade" and said it expects to follow through soon. Higher ratings can help reduce a county's interest costs.
Among county governments in New York State rated by Moody's this year, most have gone in the other direction. Nine were downgraded, 2 were placed on a watch list for downgrading and 10 were given a negative outlook. Only four were upgraded.
Local governments have been hurt by sluggish sales tax revenues and hit by rising costs for Medicaid, pensions and health insurance, Moody's said in an overview.
When the economy was booming in the 1990's, Nassau was going in the opposite direction then, too.
Despite the high average income of Nassau residents, the county government ran up annual deficits, and its long-term debt ballooned to nearly $3 billion. Nassau's credit, which had retained high ratings for more than half a century, slid to one notch above junk bonds. 
Eventually the state provided bailout aid and imposed a fiscal oversight board. The budget problems prompted voters to elect a Democratic majority to the County Legislature for the first time, and Thomas R. Suozzi was the first Democrat in three decades to win the county executive's seat.
Moody's latest report, by analyst Yaffa Rattner, said that the rating service would be scrutinizing Nassau's third-quarter fiscal report, its projections for a $54 millionyear-end surplus and the prospect that the county's sales tax revenue will be better than predicted.
Among the county's recent successes, Moody's said, were settling of its union contracts with some savings, a compromise on its sewer authority and a proposed budget for next year with no new property taxes. Moody's also praised the Suozzi administration for reducing the county work force, holding down spending and reducing the debt.
In his annual budget message two weeks ago, Mr. Suozzi had said that while most other governments were struggling to cope with their financial problems, Nassau was already on a course to control costs.. Mr. Suozzi called his budget for 2004 "solid and credible" and predicted that "it will further enhance our status with the credit rating agencies."

HEADLINE: Powell Tells Arab-Americans Of Hopes to Develop Mideast 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 29 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell came here tonight, to the American city with the biggest concentration of Arab-Americans, and said the United States was dedicated to building a prosperous and peaceful Middle East.
 Mr. Powell, speaking at an economic conference of leaders from the Middle East and hundreds of American and Arab-American executives, said millions of people in the Middle East were frustrated by joblessness and poverty. "With so much frustration," he said, "no wonder so many people are angry." 
 "I come to help you build a new Middle East," Mr. Powell said.
Echoing the Administration's call for help from other nations in Iraq, Mr. Powell said the United States "was committed to supporting Arab efforts at reform and development." But he added: "We cannot do it alone. We need partners in the region and in the international community."
He spoke of the administration's effort to develop a huge free trade zone in an area that is now hobbledwith more trade barriers than any other part of the world, and he spoke of United States programs like those that finance small-business start-ups for women and send Arab students to intern at American companies.
Summarizing developments in the region, Mr. Powell said the United States was making "remarkable progress" in Iraq, but he said the Middle East peace plan for the Israelis and the Palestinians was stalled because of continuing violence.
To move forward in Israel, he said, the Palestinians must be fully committed to fighting violence. He drew his first ripple of applause when he said that "Israel, too, has obligations," and that "settlement activity" in the West Bank "must end."
He also touched on Iran, saying the United States would not tolerate development of nuclear weapons by the government there. The International Atomic Energy Agency has given Iran a deadline of Oct. 31 to prove it is not using a nuclear power plant to enrich uranium for weapons.
Mr. Powell was in Detroit leading a delegation of nearly a dozen senior American diplomats and trade officials at a time when tensions have been running particularly high in the Middle East and when Arabs and Arab-Americans have been expressing concerns about harassment as a result of increased security measures in the United States.
Some Middle East business leaders acknowledged they are apprehensive about United States policy. After a day of listening, Hisham Abdulla al-Shirawi, an executive of a conglomerate in Dubai, the commercial center of the United Arab Emirates, said he was still worried about the "unhealthy climate" toward Arabs in America.
"You can't say the fears have been completely removed," he said. 
The organizers of the event, the American-Arab Chamber of Commerce in Dearborn, just outside Detroit, have tried to steer the talk away from politics. 
But one of the leaders of the more than 300,000 Arab-Americans living near Detroit, Osama Siblani, said side-stepping politics and the raw feelings of many Arabs toward Washington guaranteed that the conference would accomplish little.
"The biggest question right now is, 'How can Arabs or Muslims come and invest in the United States in light of the harassment and harsh treatment?' " said Mr. Siblani, chairman of the Congress of Arab American Organizations and editor and publisher of the weekly Arab American News. As for the Middle East, he said, "No one will invest in an area that is so volatile."
"The people at the conference all know each other," Mr. Siblani said. "They know how to invest. They should focus on the hardships Arabs are facing."
After addressing the conference this morning, William J. Burns, the United States special envoy to the Middle East, met with Svheil K. Gedeon, a banker who leads the Palestinian-American Chamber of Commerce in Ramallah.
Mr. Gedeon said his delegation came to the conference to demonstrate that "Palestine is there and open for business." But he added, "economic growth is going to have to rely on political improvement."

HEADLINE: Boom Times on the Poverty Roll 

 BODY:
An additional 1.7 million Americans slipped into official poverty last year, ground down by the pernicious joblessness that remains the most salient fact of the economic recovery. Job growth -- promised by Republican architects of the new tax cuts favoring the affluent -- remains a national dream. The poverty roll rose to 34.6 million people, more than a third of them children, according to new census data. And the grimness of this trend is hardly reversible in the immediate future as the president and the Republican-led Congress pay for the tax cuts, postwar Iraq and other programs with budget deficits that are projected to sap $5 trillion from the nation's revenue flow over the next decade. 
 A dark dynamic in the rising poverty is the near tripling of the long-term unemployed in the past three years, to 1.9 million formerly productive workers who have simply given up looking for jobs in the depressed market. Some of the severest poverty and unemployment rates have struck Midwest industrial states, which have suffered many of the 2.7 million payroll jobs lost during President Bush's watch. Republican lawmakers are now scurrying to cobble together some sort of job program -- an effort that seems aimed more at the voting next year in key electoral battlegrounds than at the 12 out of 100 impoverished Americans. It is hard to see these Americans as a priority of Mr. Bush in a year in which he failed to prod Congressional Republicans to reverse the cruel denial of new child-care tax credits to low-income families. 
 The ominous context for the nation's mushrooming poverty, jobless and deficit problems was spelled out yesterday by a bipartisan coalition of leading economists and business and government veterans from the Committee for Economic Development, the Concord Coalition and the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. They warned that the coming decade would doubtlessly be "the most fiscally irresponsible in our nation's history," unless the president and Congress somehow lose their cut-taxes-and-spend enthusiasm.

HEADLINE: Bonds for a Midtown Skyscraper Bring Out Supporters and Critics 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
The announcements for public hearings by the city's Industrial Development Agency are usually buried in the back of a newspaper and rarely draw more than a handful of people to consider what amounts to hundreds of millions of dollars in subsidies for private projects.
 But there was a full house on hand yesterday, about 75 people, for a debate over the merits of a $915 million, 57-story skyscraper for Bank of America at 42nd Street and the Avenue of the Americas. Critics and supporters focused on the city's plan to provide $650 million in tax-free financing known as Liberty Bonds for the bank, which would be the principal tenant, and its development partner, the Durst Organization. 
 "We've been trying to bring more sunshine to the process," said Bettina Damiani, director of Good Jobs New York and a critic of the development agency. "In that respect, this has been a huge success. It can only lead to economic development with clearer public benefits." 
Still, the directors of the Industrial Development Agency are expected to tentatively approve the special financing for the project today without getting more than a cursory report on the hearing. A number of speakers also complained yesterday that city documents detailing the Bank of America project were full of conflicting and confusing numbers.
Andrew M. Alper, chairman of the agency, acknowledged that the matter was somewhat rushed because Bank of America needed to complete the project before its current lease at 9 West 57th Street expired in 2008. But, he added, the project will have to come back to the agency for another public hearing and approval.
Mr. Alper said the bank's decision to build a new headquarters on 42nd Street was "a strong vote of confidence in New York and will do a lot to rebuild the city's economy."
The bank plans to occupy about half the proposed 2 million-square-foot skyscraper. 
But members of the Libertarian Party, a community housing group and an adjacent property owner facing condemnation criticized the city for agreeing to a huge subsidy for a wealthy bank and developer in the most desirable office district in the world. The Liberty Bonds, they said, were intended to rebuild Lower Manhattan after the attack on the World Trade Center.
John C. Whitehead, chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, issued a statement at the hearing opposing the use of Liberty Bonds for Midtown projects, because the use of the bonds downtown is "fully feasible."
Mr. Alper said the city did not see the demand downtown for all $8 billion in Liberty Bonds. The bank project, however, is not feasible without the bonds, he said.
Margaret Hughes of the Good Old Lower East Side housing organization said the money would be better spent on "creating economic development opportunities in the outer boroughs."
Ms. Damiani questioned whether the city had included adequate penalties in the event Bank of America failed to live up to its promises to keep 2,800 jobs in Manhattan and add hundreds more in the future. She said the bank had obtained $18 million in tax breaks in 1993 to bring 1,700 employees to the World Trade Center. But by 1998, the bank had cut its staff at the trade center to 830.
Members of the New York City Arts Coalition and the Environmental Justice Coalition praised the building for its environmental design but said the city should insist on a development fee for the arts and affordable housing.
The Real Estate Board of New York, the construction industry executives and the construction unions all spoke in favor of the project.

HEADLINE: For a Changing City, New Pieces in a Lead-Poisoning Puzzle 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
A single stark image has imprinted itself on the American health system about the dangers of lead: a chip of peeling paint on a child's bedroom wall and a small hand reaching up to touch. 
 More and more, though, health officials, environmentalists and doctors are being forced to look beyond that traditional explanation and into such tangled subjects as immigration, foreign trade and the transformed demographics of urban America. Old lead paint, they say, is still the major threat to most children. And many of the new threats are still wrapped in mystery and controversy. But as the New York City Council considers a new lead hazard prevention law this fall, some experts say that the answer of the past -- find every last chip of lead paint and remove it -- may no longer be enough. 
 Last year, out of about 5,000 cases of children with elevated lead levels in the city, one in four involved a child born outside the United States, according to the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Out of 40 pregnant women found to have severely elevated levels of lead in their blood, 95 percent were foreign-born -- 60 percent of them from Mexico alone, according to city figures. 
Finding the sources of lead is also getting harder. In the most serious lead cases investigated by the city last year, 35 percent could not be traced to paint at all -- a percentage that Health Department officials say is higher than in the past. (The officials added that no exact historical figures had been kept for comparison.) And among immigrant children with the most severe lead levels, the uncertainty about the source was even greater. Only about half the cases could be definitively traced to paint, health officials said.
"So many new pathways for lead have emerged," said Dr. David C. Bellinger, an associate professor in neurology at Harvard Medical School. "You can have legislation to address one, but it doesn't mean you've solved the problem." 
At the heart of that new pattern is the emergence of a new city on top of the old one. Over the last few decades, hundreds of thousands of immigrants have poured into New York City -- often into the same low-income neighborhoods where old housing and lead paint problems had festered.
Many of those immigrants came from countries and regions where lead exposures are endemic: India, Pakistan, Mexico, Eastern Europe, Africa and China. 
Many also brought along cultural products, practices and foods that have been linked in cases around the country with lead contamination, health officials say.
The implications are still unfolding, but the message is clear: lead is getting into New York's neighborhoods, and its children, in new ways.
"It's hard to separate it out -- is it from the neighborhood housing or from country of origin?" said Dr. Jessica Leighton, an assistant commissioner at the city's Health Department. "We don't usually know."
There is a profound chicken-and-egg question at the heart of lead's new arc, doctors and other lead researchers say: Are the persistent lead rates in the "lead belt" across Brooklyn and Queens the result of traditional local factors like buildings and paint? Or can they also be explained by global economics and pollution thousands of miles away? Which came first, the lead, or the people infected with it?
In many respects, lead reduction is one of the great environmental success stories of the 20th century. The biggest sources, leaded gasoline and lead solder once used on food cans, were eliminated in the 1970's and 80's. Within a few years, lead levels in children plummeted across most of the nation.
But as lead in the broader environment ebbed, the urban archipelago of New York's lead belt, and some even more seriously afflicted neighborhoods in Philadelphia, Chicago and Providence, emerged even more starkly.
These neighborhoods were mostly inhabited by poor black and Hispanic families living in old houses. Poverty's connection with lead, less obvious in earlier years when middle-class suburban children were breathing pollution from leaded gas, was reinforced. Lead, more than ever, became charged with the politics of race and social justice.
Those charged politics are playing out now in New York, even as the generalizations and assumptions about lead have become less certain. When the City Council, which is now debating a new lead abatement law to replace the one struck down earlier this year by New York's highest court, held its first public hearing on the bill several weeks ago, some demonstrators in favor of the legislation suggested that the debate would be a litmus test for racism, since most poisoning victims are minority members. 
Other supporters of the bill said they feared that the nuances of demographics and science could be used by the real estate industry to argue for watered-down requirements, or that immigrants could be blamed for their health problems because of where they came from.
There is no question that neighborhood compositions in the lead belt have changed significantly since the city's first lead paint law was enacted, in 1960.
Of the eight ZIP code districts with the highest percentage rates of elevated lead in children in 2000, for example, three had populations that were more than 50 percent foreign-born, and only one was less than 20 percent immigrant, according to federal census figures. In some of the neighborhoods in Queens with the highest percentages of children testing positive for lead, the number of immigrants has tripled just since 1980, census figures show.
But underneath those changes, the list of neighborhoods with the highest poisoning rates has largely remained stable. Advocates for the city's new paint abatement law, which would toughen cleanup requirements and make it easier for parents of lead-poisoned children to sue landlords, say that is a crucial point. Geographic constancy, they say, reinforces the conventional interpretation that old housing and paint are the problem -- sickening whoever lives there, immigrant or not.
"You have a lot of different immigration patterns, but where the kids get poisoned doesn't change very much, which suggests that the overwhelming problem is the paint," said Suzanne Mattei, the executive for the New York City field office of the Sierra Club, which has lobbied the Council to pass the new lead paint bill.
In any case, Ms. Mattei and others say, even if the new picture is less certain than the old, eliminating lead paint is something that government can do. And because the consequences of lead in a child's bloodstream are so firmly established -- down to estimates of how many I.Q. points are lost with each successively higher level of exposure -- the city has an obligation, they say, to take action where it can.
"Not all the sources of lead are under our control, but lead paint is one that the city without a doubt can control," Ms. Mattei said.
Some of the new medical research complicates that picture, suggesting that the problems of lead, while connected with poor housing, can also be compounded by poor diet.
Children who get enough calcium and iron are better able to fight off the lead that can harm their mental development, numerous medical studies say. And laboratory tests on mice -- though less conclusive -- suggest that high-fat diets can increase the body's propensity to absorb lead. Those studies have prompted city health workers to begin giving dietary advice in every lead case they investigate.
Federal health officials, in looking for patterns around the country, stress that old paint is still public enemy No. 1.
"Lead paint remains the most concentrated and readily accessible source, and nothing should detract from our interest in eliminating it," said Dr. Mary Jean Brown, chief of the lead poisoning prevention branch at the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.
But Dr. Brown said the campaign against lead was also taking health workers into the politically sensitive terrain of culture and lifestyle.
Health officials in Rhode Island said this summer they had traced a pattern of elevated lead to a deodorant called litargirio that is manufactured in the Dominican Republic and widely sold in immigrant neighborhoods. In one sample, the product contained 80 percent lead. New York health officials subsequently found high lead levels in litargirio in one of five samples purchased around the city. 
In California, researchers have linked lead-glazed pottery from Mexico to high lead levels in children. Tamarind fruit candy from Mexico has been linked to elevated lead. Of the 40 lead-poisoned mothers identified in New York City in 2001, 40 percent, city health investigators said, reported experiencing pica -- a craving for nonfood items like clay and pottery. 
Other studies are suggesting that lead problems are perhaps larger, and more hidden, than previously believed. Numerous studies have concluded, for example, that mothers with high lead levels in their blood, however they were exposed, can pass problems onto their children. But those children might show no elevated lead in their blood by the time they are tested, typically around the first grade, because without continued exposure lead dissipates in the bloodstream over time. Other research suggests that even lead levels once considered insignificant can still have subtle effects on a child's development. 
Health officials say that the lead battle's next frontier may be public education -- teaching people how to avoid or minimize lead hazards, whether these come from environmental exposure in an old neighborhood, or the treats brought back from overseas by a visiting cousin. But none of that will help the health investigators themselves, who are seeing more mixed signals and more dead ends in tracking down exposure trails.
"You're never going to be able to look and say this much is because a person is Mexican, and this much is paint; there's no way to do that on an individual basis," said Dr. Brown at the Centers for Disease Control. "These exposures are cumulative, and wherever you get it, it's bad."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Myrtle Beach, S.C.; 
A 60-Mile Strip Of Surf and Golf

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

 BODY:
MYRTLE Beach claims to be the nation's golf capital, and given its 123 golf courses, it is hard to dispute the title. The city has just invested $1 billion to improve the roads along the 60-mile-long beach strip, called the Grand Strand, home to most of the hotels and other big attractions catering to the 14 million tourists that pass through each year. The biggest news on the local business scene is a plan by Hard Rock Cafe International to build a 150-acre rock 'n' roll theme park, with a 15,000-seat outdoor theater.

AIRPORT
 Myrtle Beach International Airport, less than 20 minutes from town, gets especially busy in the spring and fall as golfers pour in. It is adding a second runway and looking for new carriers to offer direct service to more cities. Already this year, Hooters Air began nonstop flights to and from Atlanta, Newark and Baltimore. 
 Not long ago, locals drove to airports in Charlotte and elsewhere to get better fares. But Mike Wooten, president of DDC Engineers, a local engineering company, said the trend had been reversed. "People from other locations are coming here because they can get better prices now from our airport," he said.

HOTELS
The 12-story, 402-room RADISSON PLAZA (843-918-5000, $139), next to the Myrtle Beach Convention Center, is the area's newest hotel and the only one with four stars. Its restaurant, VIDALIA'S (843-918-5041), serves a fruit-laden buffet breakfast.
Other popular destinations are the KINGSTON PLANTATION (843-449-0006, $179 to $249), an oceanfront resort with convention facilities and a new health club; the HILTON MYRTLE BEACH RESORT (843-449-5000, $139 to $159), which just underwent a $15 million renovation, and the luxurious LITCHFIELD PLANTATION (843-237-9121, $220). A new 14-story MARRIOTT (843-449-8880) is scheduled to open in November next to the GRANDE DUNES golf course.

RESTAURANTS
For a power breakfast, Walt Standish, president of Beach First National Bank, recommends the CAROLINA ROADHOUSE (843-497-9911, $22 for two, including tip), a hangout for local business leaders, or the SEA CAPTAIN'S HOUSE (843-448-8082; $22).
It is usually crowded at Greg Norman's AUSTRALIAN GRILLE (843-361-0000, $90 for dinner for two, including wine and tip), on the edge of the Intracoastal Waterway. The restaurant features striking Aboriginal decor, cooked-to-order steaks and seafood, and a big wine cellar. For something more offbeat, the elegant COLLECTOR'S CAFE (843-449-9370, $70), offers Mediterranean-style seafood served amid works by local and national artists. 
The king of local restaurants may be the wood-paneled THOROUGHBREDS (843-497-2636, $90), a favorite of Joe Woodle, president of Partners Economic Development Corporation, which works to attract businesses to the area. "It may be just a little bit stuffy," Mr. Wooten said, "but what counts is that it has a quiet atmosphere to talk business, and great steaks."

ENTERTAINMENT
The CAROLINA OPRY (800-843-6779), a music variety show in a 2,200-seat arena, is a hit with visitors. So are DOLLY PARTON'S DIXIE STAMPEDE DINNER AND SHOW (800-433-4401), which features thundering buffalo, music and Southern barbecue, and the vast HOUSE OF BLUES (843-913-3740). For drinks only, Mr. Wooten favors the new CITY BAR (843-839-5483) for its martinis, blues and jazz and its proximity to HOG WILD (843-839-4227), a barbecue-and-beer joint next door.
Hitting the beaches is the most popular leisure activity, but golf is a close second. Mr. Standish favors the DUNES GOLF AND BEACH CLUB (843-449-5236), on rolling terrain that he says makes the holes more challenging than those by the ocean. But for Mr. Woodle, "there is nothing better anywhere" than the three-year-old GRANDE DUNES (843-449-8880), though he says he is also partial to the courses at TIDEWATER PLANTATION (800-446-5363) and BLACKMOOR (866-952-5555).

ON YOUR OWN
There is shopping at the MYRTLE BEACH FACTORY STORES, with 100 outlets including Eddie Bauer and the Gap, and the COLONIAL MALL, which has 90 stores and is adding a 15-screen cinema, a driving range and a salt-water aquarium. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Visitors to Myrtle Beach will find music and barbecue at Dolly Parton's Dixie Stampede. (Photo by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Left and Right in the Ivory Tower 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 A question for David Brooks ("Lonely Campus Voices," column, Sept. 27): 
 If conservative students have difficulty getting teaching jobs, why do so many appear every generation in economics, political science, many of the humanities as well as all over business and engineering schools?
And once the Democrats are back in the White House, watch how quickly the Bush administration conservatives get ivory tower jobs.

HERBERT J. GANS
New York, Sept. 28, 2003
